label: T1

text: Police said the 71 - year - old was one of three men walking on Kells Avenue at about 08:25 BST . A red car stopped beside the group. A man, described as being in his 30s with dark hair, emerged from the passenger side of the vehicle. He brandished what appeared to be a knife and aggressively demanded that the men hand over their possessions. The 71-year-old, along with the other two men, complied with the demands, fearing for their safety. The assailant quickly snatched a wallet and a mobile phone from the group before re-entering the red car, which then sped off in the direction of the town centre. Police were immediately alerted to the incident. Officers arrived within minutes and cordoned off the area to begin their investigation. Initial inquiries suggest the vehicle was a red Toyota hatchback, though full details are still emerging. Detectives are now reviewing CCTV footage from nearby properties and appealing to anyone who witnessed the incident, or saw a red car acting suspiciously in the area around that time, to contact them. The victims, although shaken, did not sustain any physical injuries.
label: T2

text: A pensioner has suffered a minor head injury after two men were assaulted and threatened with a hammer on a west Belfast street on Saturday morning.
label: T3

text: At approximately 08:25 BST on Kells Avenue, a 71-year-old man was one of three individuals walking when a red Volkswagen Golf, identified by its southern-registered number plate, stopped beside them. Two men emerged from the vehicle and assaulted two members of the group, stealing a wallet. One assailant also produced a hammer, using it to threaten the men. Police are examining a potential link between this attack and a report of criminal damage to a car on Oramnore Drive occurring concurrently. That incident involved two men in a red car reportedly smashing the windscreen and passenger window of a parked Toyota. Authorities have appealed for witnesses.
label: T4

text: Lincolnshire Police is taking on about 150 officers over the next two years. The force is restricting applications to people who have lived in the county for at least the past 12 months. The county's Police and Crime Commissioner, Marc Jones, said the advert had attracted a great deal of interest. In a statement on the force's website, Chief Constable Neil Rhodes said he wanted "the force to reflect the community it serves and for applicants to have an understanding of the county and issues facing the public of Lincolnshire". The force said it would also consider applications from those with strong connections to the county, such as members of the armed forces who have left the region to work in other areas. text: The Arsenal FC midfielder, 24, uploaded a picture from his 2014 wedding with the caption "un flwyddyn heddiw", which means "one year [ago] today". In contrast to positive responses, some users expressed confusion while others ridiculed the message. One questioned whether the FA Cup winner was "drunk" and another asked if he had "had a seizure". The tweet, posted on 8 June, attracted criticism for its lack of an English translation. Twitter user @RightJudgeIam posted: "Did you lean on the keyboard?" While @BanterousGooner said: "Did you have a seizure while typing this or something?" Arsenal fan @MegatronAFC, who describes herself as an "Aaron Ramsey enthusiast", said: "I didn't know Welsh was a language lol [sic]." Many of the tweets have since been deleted and people rushed to support Mr Ramsey on the micro-blogging site, calling the negative posts "horrible". Andrea Williams, from Rhymney, Caerphilly county, using her twitter handle @tyclyd1972, posted: "Why put such horrible status don't be jealous cause we got a different language we r proud to talk Welsh [sic]." "Good to see people like @AaronRamsey tweeting in Welsh," Ffion Elena posted. "Can only be positive for our language." Mr Ramsey, who was raised in Caerphilly, attended Welsh-medium school Ysgol Gyfun Cwm Rhymni before signing with Cardiff City's youth academy. He played in Wales' crucial 1-0 home win against Belgium on Friday and has scored nine times during his 34 appearances for his country.

text: American Troy Bradley and Russian Leonid Tiukhtyaev landed safely, their Two Eagles Balloon team said. They claim to have beaten the world distance and duration records by flying for more than 137 hours and travelling more than 5,209 miles (8,383km). To set the records the team needed to beat the existing records by 1%. "The Two Eagles balloon team is pleased to report the Two Eagles balloon has landed safely just off the Baja coast near La Poza Grande," their team said in a statement. "The pilots made a controlled descent to a gentle water landing about four miles off the Baja coast. The balloon is stable and still inflated and the pilots are fine." The two pilots left Japan on Sunday and had aimed to land in Canada or the US. However, weather forced them to change course towards Mexico. They were met in the sea by a Mexican fishing boat. The statement stressed that the sea landing was acceptable "under the international rules governing the establishment of world records". "Two around-the-world attempts using a different type of balloon landed in the water and were approved as records." The two pilots needed to beat the existing records - both set in 1981 - by 1%. For duration that meant staying aloft for about 138 hours and 45 minutes, and for distance they needed to travel about 5,260 miles. The Two Eagles Balloon team said the landing "occurred at six days, 16 hours and 37 minutes", with the pilots covering the distance of 6,646 miles. Gas-air balloons are difficult to steer, relying on the differing wind speed and direction at different altitudes. In order to change height the pilots have only a helium release valve to go down and sandbags to jettison to go up. The hi-tech "Two Eagles" balloon is made of a strong Kevlar and carbon-fibre composite, but weighs only 220 pounds (100kg). It is fitted with monitors and other instruments that track their course and compile data to be submitted to record-keepers. The specially-designed capsule sits beneath a huge helium-filled envelope and is designed to stay aloft for up to 10 days. The pilots live in a closet-like space with a very low ceiling.

text: American Troy Bradley and Russian Leonid Tiukhtyaev landed safely , their Two Eagles Balloon team said . They claim to have beaten the world distance and duration records by flying for more than 137 hours and travelling more than 5,209 miles ( 8,383 km ) . To set the records the team needed to beat the existing records by 1 % . " The Two Eagles balloon team is pleased to report the Two Eagles balloon has landed safely just off the Baja coast near La Paz, Mexico, after an epic journey across the Pacific Ocean. The successful splashdown concluded a historic flight that spanned over five days, shattering previous records for both duration and distance in a gas balloon. The team, led by American Troy Bradley and Russian Leonid Tiukhtyaev, had originally aimed for a landing in North America, possibly as far east as Kansas, but prevailing winds shifted their trajectory southward. Despite not reaching their initial optimal landing zone, the sheer scale of their achievement is undeniable. The Two Eagles Balloon team confirmed the successful landing via satellite communication and social media updates, stating that both pilots were in good spirits and uninjured. Recovery efforts were immediately initiated by support vessels dispatched to their landing coordinates. This monumental flight, which began on Saturday from Saga, Japan, pushed the boundaries of manned ballooning. Their claimed duration of more than 137 hours surpasses the previous record of 137 hours, 5 minutes, 50 seconds set by the Double Eagle II in 1978. Similarly, the claimed distance of over 5,209 miles far exceeds the existing record for a manned balloon. For official recognition by the Fédération Aéronautique Internationale (FAI), the world's air sports governing body, the Two Eagles team needed to beat the standing records by at least 1%. Based on their preliminary data, they appear to have comfortably achieved this margin for both categories. The flight path of the Eagles took them across vast expanses of the Pacific, demonstrating remarkable resilience and navigational skill from Bradley and Tiukhtyaev. The two aviators endured extreme cold, turbulent weather, and the inherent challenges of prolonged flight at high altitudes within the confines of their gondola. Their successful completion marks a significant milestone in ballooning history, validating years of planning, preparation, and technological innovation by the Two Eagles Balloon team. While awaiting official certification of their records, the mood among the team and supporters is one of immense elation and pride. This extraordinary journey not only sets new benchmarks but also inspires future generations of adventurers and aerospace engineers. The precision landing off the coast of Baja, though not the specific target, ensured the safety of the crew and the preservation of crucial flight data for record verification. It was a testament to the skill and endurance of American Troy Bradley and Russian Leonid Tiukhtyaev, who have etched their names into the annals of aviation.

text: RamJam uploaded Southern Rail Tycoon on Thursday, and so far 45,000 people have played the tongue-in-cheek game. The aim is to stop guards from boarding trains, which leads to services being cancelled as profits are collected from passengers. It was inspired by months of cancellations due to an RMT dispute. Once a sufficient number of train guards board on a train and a delayed service eventually departs, the player loses the game. Brighton-based developer Tom Jackson said: "We all were planning to go to London a month ago and trains were delayed, then delayed, then delayed and then eventually cancelled. "We were so frustrated by the whole thing that we've stopped using the trains." Mr Jackson, along with his colleagues Phil Hart and Toby Funnell, developed the game as a result of that experience. The 39-year-old said that the purpose of the game was a mixture of providing commuters with something fun to do while waiting for delayed trains and also making people aware of the compensation policy. When the game is over, links appear to the Southern Rail compensation page and twitter account. He added: "We like to do pieces that are reactive and demonstrate the impact [news events] have on people. "It's incredibly frustrating, the train service is an absolute shambles." A Southern Rail spokesman said: "Southern makes no money by cancelling trains - in fact the opposite is true. "We are trying hard to give passengers the best service possible under very difficult circumstances and apologise sincerely." The RMT union and GTR are in a dispute regarding the proposed introduction of more driver-only operated (DOO) services, which would change conductors' roles. As a result of regular walkouts, Southern cancelled 341 daily train services on 11 July to improve "reliability". Since then 15 have been reinstated. Rail minister Claire Perry resigned on Friday as a result of the months of delays on the line, managed by Govia Thameslink Railway. On Monday, new Transport Secretary Chris Grayling said resolving the strike action was "top of his priority list".
label: T1

text: RamJam uploaded Southern Rail Tycoon on Thursday , and so far 45,000 people have played the tongue - in - cheek game . The aim is to stop guards from boarding trains , which leads to services being cancelled as profits are collected from passengers . It was inspired by months of cancellations due to an RMT dispute . Once a sufficient number of train guards board on a train and a delayed service eventually departs , the player loses the round, and is presented with a screen showing plummeting profits and irate pixelated commuters storming a virtual London Victoria station. The game, created by Brighton-based indie developer Tom Jackson, under his studio moniker RamJam, has rapidly become a viral sensation. Jackson, a long-time frustrated commuter on the Southern Rail network himself, explained the inspiration behind the satirical hit: 'I spent so many hours delayed on platforms, watching those departure boards mock me, that I just had to channel that frustration into something. It started as a joke among friends, but the more I worked on 'Southern Rail Tycoon', the more I realised how many people could relate to the sheer absurdity of it all.' The game’s dark humour resonates deeply with those who have endured the real-life chaos on the network. Players must strategically deploy various humorous obstacles, from ‘broken signal’ alerts to ‘leaf on the line’ incidents, all designed to prevent guards from reaching their designated carriages. The more services cancelled, the higher the player's 'tycoon' score, reflecting their fictional mastery over the beleaguered railway. If too many services depart on time, or if guards successfully board multiple trains, the player's 'profit margin' collapses, leading to a swift game over. Despite its cynical premise, Tom Jackson insists the game is not meant to be a serious political statement, but rather a cathartic outlet. 'It’s about making light of a difficult situation,' he stated. 'It’s satire. It’s a way for people to laugh at the chaos, rather than just fuming about it. We’ve had messages from people in London, Brighton, and all along the line saying how much they appreciate being able to turn their anger into amusement, even if it’s just for a few minutes.' RamJam is now considering updates to Southern Rail Tycoon, including new scenarios and 'disaster' events, as well as a potential mobile version, cementing its status as a cult classic for exasperated commuters everywhere.

text: Halfpenny's contract at Toulon ends in summer 2016, with Cardiff Blues reported to be interested in re-signing the player. The 26-year-old left the Blues for France in the summer of 2014. The decision for Halfpenny will likely come down to a choice between the high-octane , financially rewarding world of French club rugby and the potential pull of returning home to Wales , perhaps with an eye on the 2019 World Cup and the desire to be closer to family . For the Cardiff Blues , a return for Halfpenny would be a massive coup , both on and off the field . More importantly , his presence would provide a huge boost to the region's profile and commercial appeal , potentially attracting more fans to games and increasing sponsorship opportunities . The challenge for the Blues hierarchy will be to present a compelling case to Halfpenny that transcends purely financial considerations . While other Welsh regions , particularly the Ospreys , might also express an interest should Halfpenny choose to return to Wales , the Cardiff Blues would likely hold a significant advantage given his historical ties and affinity for the club where he began his professional career . text: The ex-England Under-18 international, who made his Town debut on the final day of the season, is one of 17 players whose deals are set to expire. "It's a case of waiting to see what happens," Burton told BBC Shropshire. "There are a lot of lads out of contract here, because a lot signed two years ago," added 19-year-old Burton. Speculation has previously linked him with Wolves, Aston Villa and even Glasgow Rangers. But Newport-born Burton has witnessed the route to the top taken by England's number one, fellow Shropshire lad Joe Hart, who did a full season as Shrewsbury keeper a decade ago. "I've grown up watching the club," he said. "I want to stay and play for the team as much as I can. We will have to see what happens to everyone. "It feels like I've been waiting a long time to get on the pitch, because I've been here since I was 10. But I couldn't wish to make my debut for a better team." The League One club have until 23 May to tell their soon-to-be out-of-contract players if they want to keep them or not. Shrewsbury, who finished 20th, remained at the third tier of English football by four points in the end, having secured their safety on the penultimate weekend of the season. Town boss Micky Mellon last week revealed that he is to remain as manager next season, following their relegation near-miss.

text: The ex - England Under-18 international , who made his Town debut on the final day of the season , is one of 17 players whose deals are set to expire . " It 's a case of waiting to see what happens , " Burton told BBC Shropshire . "It's a huge period for retention and recruitment. Players naturally have their own aspirations, and we understand some will be seeking new challenges or a step up." Burton admitted the club's financial reality often limits their ability to compete with bigger clubs. "When quality players are available on a free, there's always interest," he explained. "Clubs higher up, like Wolves or Aston Villa, constantly scout for talent. Our role is to convince players that Town offers the right development platform and ambition, not just to match lucrative offers." He stressed the importance of the club's project over purely financial incentives. Despite the scale, the manager remained cautiously optimistic. "We've had positive discussions with key players we want to retain. It's a two-way street, and we're working hard to secure their futures. For others, it might be time to move on," he added. "We'll also actively bring in new faces to strengthen the squad, ensuring we're more competitive for the Town faithful next season." The coming weeks will be crucial as Burton oversees this significant rebuilding phase, as reported by BBC Shropshire.

text: Macauley Bonne gave the U's a 69th-minute lead, but the Spireites, who played more than 70 minutes with 10 men, soon equalised with a penalty. "Teams are vulnerable after they've scored. Our game management has got to be a lot better," said Keen, whose side are winless in 17 league games. "But mentally it's a tough place when you haven't won for a long time." Colchester remain bottom of the League One table, eight points behind Chesterfield, who occupy 20th place. "There was a few nerves out there as we hadn't won for a while," midfielder Owen Garvan told BBC Essex. "I thought us going ahead might calm us down a bit, but the opposite happened and too many individual mistakes are costing us." Despite Gary Liddle's sending off and Bonne's effort, the U's allowed Lee Novak to convert from the spot after he was felled by Richard Brindley. And Garvan was frustrated by his side's lack of creativity in the final third. "We had a lot of the ball, but we didn't make the keeper work too much. That's the most disappointing thing - we didn't create enough chances," the 28-year-old added. "It's the easy option to just go long and you're kind of counting on luck. If you want to be good, you have to try to break them down with good play - that's where our goal came from."

text: Macauley Bonne gave the U 's a 69th - minute lead , but the Spireites , who played more than 70 minutes with 10 men , soon equalised with a penalty . " Teams are vulnerable after they 've scored . Our game management has got to be a lot better , " said Keen , whose side whose side, Colchester United, ultimately succumbed to a frustrating 2-1 defeat against Chesterfield. "It's infuriating to concede almost immediately after you've taken the lead, especially when you have a man advantage for such a significant period of the game," Keen lamented, his frustration palpable. "Macauley Bonne took his goal so well, a really good finish, and that should have been the turning point for us to go on and secure all three points. Instead, we mentally switched off, allowed them back into the game far too easily, and then failed to respond adequately to their eventual winner. The penalty decision itself was debatable, yes, but our reaction to it and the subsequent equaliser was simply non-existent. We talk about showing character and resilience, but today we displayed very little of it when it truly mattered most. We need to be far more professional, more focused, and much more streetwise. The players have to grasp the fact that every single minute of every game counts, especially when you are fighting for every point in a demanding division like this. We allowed ourselves to be severely punished for a clear lack of concentration and game management. This isn't the first time we've let a strong position slip, and it's a worrying pattern that we absolutely, unequivocally must break. It's simply not good enough. We effectively gifted them a point, and ultimately, three. We've got to be more ruthless in seeing games out, both in our attacking play and, crucially, in our defensive discipline. We're creating enough chances, which is a positive, but we're conceding soft goals at the other end. That combination is a recipe for disaster. We need to be tougher, both physically and mentally, to grind out results. This outcome feels like a massive, massive missed opportunity, one that could potentially cost the U's dearly as the season progresses. We simply cannot afford these lapses in concentration if we are to climb the league table and achieve our objectives.

text: Colin Capp, 23, of Scotland, attacked Darren Thomas, 45, while he slept in their cell on Wing B. Consultant forensic psychiatrist Dr Melanie Croy told the jury Mr Capp's ability to form rational judgement was impaired because of his mental illness. Mr Capp admits killing Mr Thomas but denies murder. Appearing for the defence, Dr Croy, who works at Ashworth high security hospital where Mr Capp has been detained, said he suffered from an abnormality of mental function, which could diminish his responsibility for Mr Thomas's murder. Dr Croy told the court Mr Capp suffered from paranoid delusional beliefs and heard two voices in his head. One, which he describes as Mr Grey, tells him to harm others and himself, the jury was told. Since he has been at Ashworth hospital, Mr Capp has described voices telling him to kill others with his bare hands, she said. A second female voice acts as a guardian and gives him advice, the court was told. Mr Capp told Dr Croy he believed he was being tortured at Cardiff prison in the weeks leading to the killing and thought he was going to be killed. A different consultant psychiatrist, on behalf of the prosecution, believes Mr Capp has a personality disorder rather than a mental illness. Dr Phillip Joseph told the jury he believed Mr Capp understood what he was doing when he killed his cellmate. MrThomas was discovered dead in the cell with a plastic bag wrapped around his head. He had been stabbed 100 times in the neck with a ball point pen. Mr Capp denies murder on the grounds of diminished responsibility. The trial continues.
label: T1

text: Colin Capp , 23 , of Scotland , attacked Darren Thomas , 45 , while he slept in their cell on Wing B. Consultant forensic psychiatrist Dr Melanie Croy told the jury Mr Capp 's ability to form rational judgement was impaired because of his mental illness . Mr Capp admits killing Mr Thomas but denies murder . Appearing for the prosecution, Mr. John Smith QC, told the jury that while Mr Capp's mental health issues were acknowledged, they did not amount to a defence of diminished responsibility or negate the intent to kill. He argued that the brutal nature of the attack on Mr Thomas, carried out while he was vulnerable and asleep in their shared cell on Wing B, demonstrated a clear intention. Mr Smith highlighted the evidence of pre-meditation, suggesting Mr Capp had planned the assault. Dr Croy, cross-examined by the prosecution, reiterated her assessment that Mr Capp suffered from paranoid schizophrenia, leading to a severely distorted perception of reality. She elaborated on his delusional beliefs, which had intensified in the confined environment of Wing B, particularly in relation to his cellmate, Mr Thomas. She stated that while he understood the physical act of killing, his capacity for moral judgment and rational decision-making was profoundly compromised. Prison officers also described Mr Capp's erratic behaviour in the days leading up to the attack. The defence, led by Ms Sarah Jones, countered that Mr Capp's actions were a direct consequence of his severe mental illness, which had been inadequately managed within the prison system. Ms Jones emphasised Dr Croy's expert opinion, arguing Mr Capp suffered from an abnormality of mental functioning which substantially impaired his ability to understand his conduct, form rational judgment, or exercise self-control. She painted a picture of a young man from Scotland whose untreated condition spiralled out of control, leading to the tragic death of Darren Thomas. The trial continues, with further medical evidence expected before deliberations begin on the complex interplay between mental health and criminal culpability.
label: T2

text: An inmate who stabbed his cellmate to death with a pen at Cardiff prison was suffering from paranoid schizophrenia, Cardiff crown court has heard.

text: Scottish inmate Colin Capp, 23, assaulted his 45-year-old cellmate, Darren Thomas, as he slept in their Wing B cell. Consultant forensic psychiatrist Dr. Melanie Croy testified to the jury that Mr. Capp's capacity for rational judgment was impaired by his mental illness. Mr. Capp admits to causing Mr. Thomas's death but denies murder. Appearing for the defence, Dr. Croy, from Ashworth high-security hospital where Mr. Capp is detained, stated that he suffered from an abnormality of mental function, which could diminish his responsibility for Mr. Thomas's killing. Dr. Croy further informed the court that Mr. Capp experienced paranoid delusional beliefs and heard two voices. One voice, identified as 'Mr. Grey,' reportedly instructs him to harm himself and others, the jury heard. She added that since his time at Ashworth Hospital, Mr. Capp has described voices commanding him to kill people with his bare hands. Conversely, a second, female voice acts as a protective guardian, offering him advice, the court was told. Mr. Capp told Dr. Croy he believed he was being tortured at Cardiff prison in the weeks leading up to the incident and feared he would be killed. In contrast, a separate consultant psychiatrist for the prosecution, Dr. Phillip Joseph, contended that Mr. Capp has a personality disorder rather than a mental illness. Dr. Joseph told the jury he believed Mr. Capp understood his actions when he killed his cellmate. Mr. Thomas's body was discovered in the cell with a plastic bag over his head and approximately 100 stab wounds to the neck inflicted by a ballpoint pen. Mr. Capp's defence rests on a plea of not guilty to murder due to diminished responsibility. The trial remains ongoing.
label: T4

text: It comes after Darren 'Birdie' Bird's image - showing the mascot "paying his respects" to Sir Terry, who died on Sunday - was shared thousands of times on social media. text: West Yorkshire Police confirmed last month that 16,000 tickets issued by police community support officers (PCSO) were not valid due because of an "administrative error". But, the force said there was "no basis in law" for refunds, which would have "come from the public purse". Many of the drivers paid up without challenging the ticket's validity. After a review of PCSO powers in March, the force found some PCSOs who joined the force several years ago were not initially given powers to issue parking tickets. In a statement, police said "an administrative error meant that the authorisation was invalid". The force's current records system, which goes back to 2006, found 16,000 tickets were affected, resulting in total of ¬£485,000 being paid to the courts. The force admitted other tickets may have been issued in similar circumstances for up to three years earlier. It said it had taken legal advice on the matter. A spokesman said: "We are now satisfied that there is no basis in law that would entitle anyone to such a refund, which would in any case have had to come from the public purse. At the heart of this assessment is that motorists had opportunity to challenge the validity of the process in court at the time, and only those found guilty in these circumstances were penalised. "If, however, motorists elected to pay the penalty they effectively accepted having committed the offence and opted out of the court process, thereby waiving their right to contest the matter." The force said the "anomaly" had since been corrected and PCSOs now had the full powers to issue the fines.

text: West Yorkshire Police confirmed last month that 16,000 tickets issued by police community support officers ( PCSO ) were not valid due because of an " administrative error " . But , the force said there was " no basis in law " for refunds , which would have " come from the public purse " . Many of the drivers paid the fines, unaware of the underlying error. The revelation sparked considerable public outcry and anger among those affected, who felt unfairly penalised by the West Yorkshire Police. Drivers expressed frustration that the force was acknowledging the invalidity of the tickets while simultaneously refusing any form of recompense. Legal experts weighed in, questioning the ethical implications of retaining funds collected unlawfully, even if there was no direct legal precedent for a refund. Some argued that while the law might not explicitly mandate refunds in such a unique administrative error scenario, the principle of unjust enrichment should apply, where one party should not benefit from another's loss caused by their own mistake. The situation put the West Yorkshire Police under significant pressure to explain why such a fundamental error occurred and why transparency about the issue took so long. Critics pointed out that the public's trust in the police, particularly in the impartiality and correctness of their enforcement actions, could be severely damaged. The Police and Crime Commissioner for West Yorkshire acknowledged the serious nature of the administrative error and stated that a full internal review was underway to understand how the invalid tickets were issued by PCSOs for such an extended period without detection. This review aimed to identify weaknesses in the internal processes and implement robust measures to prevent a recurrence. For the many individuals who had already paid their tickets, often under the threat of further penalties or points on their license, the news was a bitter pill. Some indicated they would explore avenues for collective legal action, seeking advice on whether a class-action lawsuit could compel the force to refund the monies. Consumer rights groups also got involved, advocating on behalf of the affected drivers and calling for a clearer legal framework to address situations where administrative errors by public bodies lead to financial detriment for citizens. The incident highlighted a significant loophole in the system, where a clear administrative blunder by the West Yorkshire Police left thousands of citizens out of pocket with seemingly no recourse, raising fundamental questions about accountability and citizen protection when dealing with official enforcement. The cost of individual legal challenges for the drivers would likely outweigh the value of the tickets, further complicating their options. The PCSO role and the scope of their powers were also re-examined in light of the incident.
label: T2

The force's records, accessible back to 2006, revealed that 16,000 tickets were impacted, leading to a total of £485,000 being paid into the courts. The force also conceded that other fines might have been issued under similar incorrect circumstances up to three years earlier. They confirmed seeking legal counsel on the issue. A spokesperson explained that, after legal assessment, they are confident there are no legal grounds for refunds, which would otherwise use public money. The core reasoning is that drivers had the opportunity to dispute the tickets' validity in court at the time, and penalties were only imposed on those found guilty. By choosing to pay the fine, motorists effectively accepted responsibility for the offence and forfeited their right to challenge it legally. The police confirmed that this "anomaly" has since been rectified, and PCSOs now possess the full authority to issue such fines.
label: T4

text: Four men deny attempting to smuggle 35 people into Tilbury Docks, Essex. One man died in the container. Basildon Crown Court heard one defendant been caught in France with migrants in the back of his lorry 11 days before the Tilbury incident. Timothy Murphy from Londonderry was fined √Ç¬£5,000 in August. Prosecutor Michael Goodwin told the court how 12 Afghans had been found in a locker in Mr Murphy's lorry transporting frozen chips from Coquelles, France, to the UK on 5 August. "This was not a case of an energetic migrant chasing after and jumping on board in an attempt to smuggle their way on board," he said. "There were 12 people inside that locker. They did not end up there by chance." Mr Goodwin said as Mr Murphy drove the lorry to Coquelles he was in regular contact with fellow defendants Stephen McLaughlin and Martin McGlinchey. The group of 35 Afghan Sikhs was found in the container at Tilbury 11 days after that incident, on 16 August. Mr Goodwin told the court how dock workers heard noises inside the container and opened it up, finding those inside distressed and struggling to breathe. Meet Singh Kapoor, 40, had died in the overnight crossing from Zeebrugge, Belgium. Mr McLaughlin, 34, of Limavady, Londonderry; Mr Murphy, 33, of Elmgrove, Londonderry; Mr McGlinchey, 47, of Derryloughan Road, Coalisland, County Tyrone; and Taha Sharif, 38, who is Kurdish and lived in Tottenham, London, at the time, have all pleaded not guilty to conspiracy to facilitate illegal entry into the UK. The trial is expected to last up to six weeks.

text: Four men deny attempting to smuggle 35 people into Tilbury Docks , Essex . One man died in the container . Basildon Crown Court heard one defendant been caught in France with migrants in the back of his lorry 11 days before the Tilbury incident . Timothy Murphy from Londonderry was fined √Ç¬£5,000 in August . Prosecutor Michael Goodwin told the court that the 35 migrants, including 15 children, were discovered on August 16 last year inside a container on the MV Titania, which had arrived at Tilbury Docks from Zeebrugge, Belgium. Conditions within the sealed container were described as “inhumane and life-threatening,” with temperatures soaring and oxygen levels depleting rapidly during the 10-hour voyage. The court heard that the victims had been deliberately locked inside the unit. Mr. Goodwin explained that port officials heard unusual noises coming from within the container. Upon opening it, they found terrified and struggling individuals, many suffering from severe dehydration and hyperthermia. Among them was Meet Singh, 47, from Afghanistan, who tragically died during the journey. A post-mortem examination concluded that his death was caused by a combination of dehydration and hyperthermia. The prosecution alleges that the four defendants, Stephen McLaughlin, 31; Martin McGlinchey, 49; Christopher Murphy, 20; and Timothy Murphy, 33, all from Londonderry, were part of an organised criminal conspiracy to smuggle people into the UK for financial gain. Mr. Goodwin highlighted Timothy Murphy's previous conviction in France, where he was caught attempting to transport 15 migrants in his lorry. This incident, just days before the Tilbury tragedy, suggested a sophisticated and repeated enterprise. The court heard evidence that the defendants had been in regular contact via burner phones, coordinating their movements leading up to the incident. CCTV footage and phone data linked them to the vehicle carrying the container and to locations near Zeebrugge. The prosecution argued that the defendants were fully aware of the dangerous conditions the migrants would endure and showed a callous disregard for human life. All four defendants deny a charge of conspiracy to facilitate illegal entry into the UK and a charge of manslaughter in relation to Mr. Singh’s death. The trial at Basildon Crown Court is expected to last several weeks, with further evidence to be presented regarding the planning and execution of the smuggling operation and the role each defendant played. The focus remains on establishing the extent of their knowledge and involvement in this tragic event, which ultimately cost a man his life and put dozens of others in extreme peril at Tilbury Docks in Essex.

The decision to split the tournament across multiple international venues – first the UAE, then Bangladesh, and finally back to India – highlights the logistical complexities and flexibility required to manage such a massive sporting event amidst national priorities. The cricket board has prioritised the safety of players and fans, making necessary adjustments to the IPL schedule. While South Africa has hosted parts of the IPL in the past, the current arrangements in the UAE and Bangladesh were deemed most suitable given the timing and logistical considerations. text: The life - size bronze effigy of the Native American stands in Gravesend , Kent , where she died on her journey home to Virginia in 1617 . Historic England has renewed its Grade II listed status and updated details of her life and role in Transatlantic history , confirming the monument's significance in commemorating Pocahontas, known also as Matoaka. The statue, erected in 1958, serves as a poignant reminder of her brief but impactful time in England, where she was presented to King James I and Queen Anne. Her story embodies the early, complex interactions between European settlers and Native American communities, particularly her marriage to English tobacco planter John Rolfe, which was instrumental in a period of peace for the early Jamestown colony. The updated Historic England listing now explicitly acknowledges her Algonquian heritage and the often-misrepresented narratives surrounding her life, highlighting the agency she exercised within challenging circumstances. This recognition underscores the effigy's importance not merely as a local landmark in Gravesend, Kent, but as a national symbol of a pivotal moment in global history. The Grade II listing ensures the continued preservation of this unique memorial, reflecting its special architectural and historical interest. It emphasizes her tragic death at a young age in Gravesend before she could return to her native Virginia, underscoring the profound human cost of early colonial expansion and intercultural exchange. The statue, therefore, invites contemplation on themes of cultural encounter, diplomacy, and the lasting legacy of those who bridged vastly different worlds.

text: They lost by seven wickets after being bowled out for just 90 in a rain-shortened match at the Riverside. "We fell a long way short. text: They lost by seven wickets after being bowled out for just 90 in a rain - shortened match at the Riverside . " We fell a long way short . "When you're chasing such a low total, you expect your top order to step up and build a foundation, but we just never got going. It was a really poor performance from start to finish, especially considering the conditions were easing. We knew Worcestershire would come hard at us, and they did, but we simply crumbled under the pressure. It's frustrating because we've shown glimpses of what we can do in other games at the Riverside, but this was a significant step backwards." Durham captain Scott Borthwick added, "It's certainly not what we wanted. We prepared well, but the execution wasn't there. Losing early wickets put us on the back foot, and we couldn't recover. Credit to Worcestershire, they bowled exceptionally well and put us under constant pressure. We need to learn from this quickly and ensure we bounce back strongly in our next fixture. We have a lot of talented players in this squad, and we know we're capable of much better. We'll be working hard to address the issues that arose today and come back stronger." Fast bowler Chris Rushworth, a key figure for Durham, echoed the sentiment of disappointment. "It's tough to take," Rushworth commented. "We pride ourselves on our fight, and today we just didn't show enough of it. Dropping catches and misfields at crucial moments didn't help our cause either. We gave away too many easy runs and then failed to make enough ourselves. It's a collective failure, and we all need to look in the mirror." text: Fewer animals were counted on Scotland's east coast and in Orkney in surveys by St Andrews University Sea Mammal Research Unit. But the work commissioned by Scottish Natural Heritage (SNH), found an increase in harbour seals on the west coast. Between Cape Wrath and Ullapool, 1,095 animals were recorded. In 2008, a survey counted 2,687. Sightings of harbour seals, also known as common seals, have been declining for several years, with the latest research suggesting the trend is continuing. Between Aberlady Bay in East Lothian, 213 were spotted compared with 459 seven years ago. The unit did not have enough time to survey the coast from Aberlady Bay down to the Scottish Borders. At the Firth of Tay and Eden Estuary Special Area of Conservation, 50 seals were counted - the lowest figure so far recorded in that area. Previously, 78 were seen. In Orkney, the latest research recorded 1,865 compared with 2,687 in 2010.
label: T1

text: Fewer animals were counted on Scotland 's east coast and in Orkney in surveys by St Andrews University Sea Mammal Research Unit . But the work commissioned by Scottish Natural Heritage ( SNH ) , remains critical for informing conservation efforts, particularly given these concerning findings. The comprehensive surveys undertaken by the St Andrews University Sea Mammal Research Unit provide vital baseline data on marine mammal populations, including seals and cetaceans, in key areas like Orkney and along Scotland's east coast. This long-term monitoring is indispensable for identifying the drivers behind such declines, whether they are linked to climate change, prey availability shifts, or human activities such as increased shipping or offshore development. SNH relies on this detailed scientific evidence to develop robust management plans and advocate for policies that protect these vulnerable species and their habitats across Scotland's marine environment.

text: Numbers of harbour seals in Scotland have continued fall, according to a new report.

text: Surveys by St Andrews University's Sea Mammal Research Unit (SMRU), commissioned by Scottish Natural Heritage (SNH), indicate fewer seals on Scotland's east coast and in Orkney. Overall, sightings of harbour (or common) seals have been declining for several years, a trend confirmed by the latest research. A survey in 2008 counted 2,687, highlighting a significant drop since. For example, Aberlady Bay in East Lothian recorded 213 seals, down from 459 seven years prior. The Firth of Tay and Eden Estuary Special Area of Conservation saw its lowest figure yet with 50 seals, compared to a previous 78. In Orkney, 1,865 seals were recorded, a decrease from 2,687 in 2010. Time constraints prevented the unit from surveying the coast from Aberlady Bay to the Scottish Borders. Conversely, the west coast showed a rise in harbour seal numbers, with 1,095 found between Cape Wrath and Ullapool.

text: This Is For My Girls was written by Diane Warren - whose previous credits include I Don't Want To Miss A Thing and Un-Break My Heart. She described the song - a strident, girl power anthem - as "We Are the World meets Lady Marmalade". Obama released the single ahead of her keynote speech at the SXSW festival. She will talk about her Let Girls Learn initiative, which is aimed at boosting education rates amongst adolescent girls around the world. Several of the performers on the track, including Missy Elliott and Diane Warren, will then join her on a panel about the initiative, as well as Sophia Bush and Queen Latifah, who will moderate the discussion. This Is For My Girls combines jazzy horn stabs with a propulsive drum beat, giving the song a militaristic feel. The lyrics mostly comprise generic statements of empowerment - "Don't take nothing from nobody"; "It's all about respect"; "Stand strong forever" - which have been a standard component of female-fronted R&B since the turn of the millennium. Other vocalists featured on the track include Janelle Monae, Glee actress Lea Michele, Disney star Zendaya, 16-year-old Motown artist Jadagrace, and Beyonce proteges Chloe & Halle. All of the artists waived their fees, meaning proceeds will go directly to the Let Girls Learn campaign. "We haven't had an anthem like this in a while," Warren told Billboard. "I envisioned the record being with all these different women, never just one girl singing on it. "With Kelly Rowland on it, it's almost like an updated Destiny's Child record. I think it can be a huge worldwide anthem. I hope it becomes that." The single is available exclusively on iTunes, while Obama's speech at the SXSW festival will be streamed live on makers.com from 16:00 GMT.

text: The firm plans to introduce a new fleet of 52 driver-only-operated (DOO) trains from 2020. None of the permanent guards or guard managers would be forced to quit their employment, the company said. RMT union said it was in formal dispute with Merseyrail and its 220 members would be balloted for strike action. John Tilley, of RMT, said Merseyrail had failed to give cast iron assurances on the future of 220 guards and managers at a meeting on Wednesday, and he "fully expected" members to vote heavily for industrial action. RMT general secretary Mick Cash said: "We will not agree to any extensions of DOO and will fight to retain the safety critical role of the guard and to keep a guard on the train." He said the train operator had "snubbed" a final chance to avoid the ballot. He added it was "entirely preventable if the company had listened to the union's deep-seated safety concerns... and had put passenger safety before profit". Merseyrail said it had "made it clear" that it will look after guards and management whose roles would no longer exist once the new fleet is introduced and there would be no compulsory redundancies. The train operator said the RMT had demanded there should be a guard on every new train but the new fleet had been designed to operate without guards, and as such, it was not in a position to guarantee this. The existing Merseyrail fleet, originally designed in the 1950s, is almost 40 years old.

text: The firm plans to introduce a new fleet of 52 driver - only - operated ( DOO ) trains from 2020 . Removing guards undermines safety and accessibility. We won't let Merseyrail put profits over people. Our members are resolute; we'll vigorously campaign to protect the guard's role and ensure safe services. This fight is about safety and security, especially in emergencies. text: It was announced on Wednesday that the East Midlands Congenital Heart Centre, at Glenfield Hospital, was to stop children's surgery services. It was one of 10 units under review nationally with the intention to focus expertise in fewer locations. The charity Heartlink said it would not accept the judgement. A spokesman for the charity, John Rigby, said: "We're going to take stock, listen to what our reps have to say and be guided by them. We're going to fight to do our very best to keep children's services here [at Glenfield]." The centre, which conducts about 230 operations on children and 70 on adults each year, has the UK's largest ECMO unit (a form of partial cardiopulmonary bypass) which oxygenates blood of critically ill patients. The unit will stop surgery for children but will remain open to diagnose patients and for monitoring and non-surgical treatment. It serves a population of about five million, with the next nearest similar unit in Birmingham, about 40 miles (64.4km) away. Leslie Hamilton, vice chair of the Safe and Sustainable review's steering group, said that as surgeons they felt surgical expertise was spread too thinly around the country. He said: "We felt we had to concentrate the expertise and reduce the number of centres in the country so we could have bigger centres with bigger surgical teams. "That would lead to sustainable care for the future and also a big improvement in care." Tony Fowlston has a three-year-old son, Lewis, who has been treated at Glenfield. The family travels a distance of about 60 miles (96.5km) from Boston, in Lincolnshire, to see specialists. He said travelling any further could be a real issue as Lewis recently suffered a cardiac arrest shortly after arriving at Glenfield. Mr Fowlston said: "He could have had that cardiac arrest on the way to, say, Birmingham. Could he have had the same service in the back of an ambulance? I very much doubt it." A petition to save the unit attracted more than 100,000 signatures.
label: T1

text: It was announced on Wednesday that the East Midlands Congenital Heart Centre , at Glenfield Hospital , was to stop children 's surgery services . It was one of 10 units under review nationally with the intention to focus expertise in fewer locations . The charity Heartlink said it would not accept the judgement . A spokesman for the charity , John Rigby , said : " We 're going to take stock , listen to what our reps have said, and then we will plan our next steps. This is absolutely not the end of the fight for the East Midlands Congenital Heart Centre. We believe this decision is flawed and will ultimately harm children and families across the UK. Heartlink will explore every avenue, including legal challenges and further campaigning, to reverse this damaging judgement." This decision, part of NHS England's 'Safe and Sustainable' review, aims to consolidate specialist services into fewer, larger centres to improve outcomes for children with complex congenital heart conditions. While proponents cite better surgical results and comprehensive care through concentrated expertise, opponents like Heartlink argue that closing established units, especially those with strong reputations, fragments care and increases travel burden for families in regions like the East Midlands. Glenfield Hospital's children's heart unit is also uniquely known for its Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) service, a vital life support system for failing hearts and lungs. It is one of only four paediatric ECMO centres in the UK. Though the ECMO service wasn't explicitly part of the surgical closure, clinicians and parents worry about the long-term viability of a specialist ECMO unit without a co-located surgical team. This interdependency is a core argument for campaigners like John Rigby, who fear that dismantling the surgical component will inevitably weaken or lead to the loss of the ECMO service, a crucial national resource. The future of specialist paediatric care in the UK is now under intense scrutiny, with questions raised about whether centralisation truly benefits all.

text: Hina Rabbani Khar's remarks came hours after the two armies agreed to "de-escalate" tensions after a meeting of their chiefs of operations. Tensions have risen following deadly exchanges along the border last week. The violence has plunged the neighbours into the worst crisis in relations since the Mumbai attacks of 2008, blamed on militants based in Pakistan. "Instead of issuing belligerent statements by the military and political leaders from across the border and ratcheting up tension, it is advisable for the two countries to discuss all concerns related to Line of Control (LoC) with a view to reinforcing respect for the ceasefire," Ms Khar's office said. AFP news agency quotes her as saying that the recent border clashes had "created questions" and added that Pakistan was "open" to dialogue between foreign ministers to end the dispute. India has not commented on Ms Khar's remarks so far. On Wednesday the Pakistani army's director of military operations agreed to the de-escalation after calling his Indian counterpart to "protest strongly" a "ceasefire violation" by Indian soldiers that killed a Pakistani soldier along the LoC on Tuesday night. India has denied the allegation, which comes after separate incidents last week, in which two Indian soldiers and two Pakistani soldiers died. The Pakistani commander said strict orders had been passed to troops on the LoC to observe a ceasefire that has been in place since 2003, a spokesman for the Indian army, Col Jagdeep Dahiya, told the BBC. Both sides deny provoking the clashes, amid fears that a fledgling peace process under way since last February could unravel, says the BBC's Sanjoy Majumder in Delhi. On Tuesday, Indian PM Manmohan Singh said the killing of the Indian soldiers last week - one of whom India says was beheaded - was "unacceptable". Claimed by both countries, Kashmir has been a flashpoint for over 60 years and two wars have been fought over it. Exchanges of fire in the disputed area are not uncommon but rarely result in fatalities.
label: T1

text: Cormack, a former chief executive of Aberdeen, sold his software company for ¬£630m last year. "I can offer both financial support and my time to the club," Cormack told the Aberdeen website. "I look forward to attracting American investment and strategic partnerships [to] help AFC maximise its potential." Cormack will work with existing board members, including chairman Stewart Milne, while splitting his time between Atlanta and the north east of Scotland. The 58-year-old was interim chief executive of the Pittodrie club between 2000 and 2001 during a sabbatical from his business interests in the USA. He is seeking to "work with the management team at AFC to explore some innovative ideas I've seen work Stateside". Cormack returns to the club after selling the software company that he helped to grow from a firm employing 12 people in 2004 to a 500-strong workforce, generating ¬£107m in annual revenues, in 2016. "While I have continued to support and provide advice to the club for many years, I'm honoured to be back on the board," Cormack said. "The club's performance in recent seasons, both on and off the pitch, is a testament to how hard everyone at Pittodrie has worked. "Having a team that is performing well and a club that is debt-free is an enviable position to be in. But we must fully exploit opportunities to increase revenues and our fanbase. "I'm looking forward to working with the existing leadership team at the club, with whom I've already got a great relationship. "Between us, and with the support of our fans, I'm sure we can get the club into a position where increased revenues, an expanded fanbase, and a state-of the-art community stadium and training campus will position AFC well to exploit changes that evolve in European club competition." Milne welcomed Cormack's involvement and the experience he will bring to the club. "Running a club in the modern era is increasingly challenging and we will greatly benefit from having someone with Dave's expertise, experience, enthusiasm and commitment," the Aberdeen chairman said. "He brings a new perspective along with an innovative approach and commercial acumen to help meet the challenges head-on."

text: Investigators think the blast was caused by a female suicide bomber from the Islamic State group. Correspondents say Turkey is cracking down on the militants, after previously being accused of ignoring them. But the blast triggered violent protest in Istanbul, with police using water cannon, teargas and rubber bullets. Friday's bomb hit a group of youth activists planning to cross into Syria to help rebuild the town of Kobane. A video shows the group holding a news conference to discuss their plans, when an explosion rips through the young people - mostly of university age - gathered in the grounds of a cultural centre. They had been chanting slogans and were holding a large banner with the words "We defended it together, we are building it together." Kobane is just across the border from Suruc and has been the site of fierce fighting between IS and Kurdish fighters. It was retaken by the Kurds in January. Suruc houses many refugees who have fled the fighting in Kobane. Kobane: Inside the town devastated by fight against IS The attack took place just before noon local time (09:00 GMT). Around a hundred people were injured. Mr Davutoglu said initial findings suggested it was the work of IS. "Turkey has taken and will continue to take all necessary measures against Islamic State," Mr Davutoglu told a news conference in Ankara. "We are face to face with a terrorism incident. We have the willpower to find and certainly punish those who are responsible." "Measures on our border with Syria... will be increased," he added. BBC Middle East correspondent Jim Muir says Turkey has been widely accused of turning a blind eye to IS activities, but recently it has been cracking down harder on the militants and this may be one reason for the attack. The country's leaders seem likely to toughen their line even further in its wake, he adds. There were large scale demonstrations in cities across the country. Protests in Istanbul and Ankara turned violent as police clashed with protesters. A witness told the Reuters news agency that hundreds of protesters in Istanbul chanted slogans accusing Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of collaboration with IS. Earlier in the day, the president condemned the attack. "On behalf of my people, I curse and condemn the perpetrators of this brutality," he said while visiting Cyprus. "Terror must be condemned no matter where it comes from." A spokesman for the White House condemned the attack and expressed "solidarity with the Turkish government and the Turkish people".

text: Investigators think the blast was caused by a female suicide bomber from the Islamic State group . Correspondents say Turkey is cracking down on the militants , after previously being accused of ignoring them . But the blast triggered violent protest in Istanbul , with police using water cannon , teargas and rubber bullets . Friday 's bomb hit a group of youth activists planning to cross into Syria to help rebuild the town of Kobane . A video shows the group holding a news conference to discuss their plans , when an explosion rips through the crowd. The chaotic footage, widely circulated online, shows bodies strewn across the ground, thick smoke billowing upwards, and survivors screaming amidst the debris. At least 32 people were killed in the attack in Suruc, a town bordering Syria, and over 100 were wounded. The vast majority of the victims were members of the Federation of Socialist Youth Associations (SGDF), who had gathered at the Amara Culture Centre before their planned journey to Kobane. Their mission was to help reconstruct the Syrian Kurdish town, which had been devastated by a four-month siege by Islamic State militants last year before being liberated by Kurdish forces. The Turkish authorities swiftly identified the perpetrator as a female suicide bomber with suspected links to the Islamic State group, also known as ISIS or Daesh. This attack marked a significant escalation of the conflict onto Turkish soil, putting immense pressure on President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s government. Critics had long accused Ankara of turning a blind eye to, or even tacitly supporting, hardline Islamist groups in Syria as part of its strategy to undermine President Bashar al-Assad. However, following the Suruc bombing, Turkey vowed a more aggressive stance. Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu condemned the 'barbaric' act and pledged to intensify efforts against all terrorist organizations. The blast immediately ignited widespread outrage and protests across Turkey, especially in Istanbul, where demonstrators clashed violently with police. The previously mentioned use of water cannon, teargas, and rubber bullets underscores the ferocity of these confrontations, as protesters accused the government of complicity or negligence in failing to prevent such an attack. Many felt the bombing was a direct consequence of Turkey's perceived inaction against Islamic State, particularly along its lengthy border with Syria, which has been a conduit for foreign fighters joining militant groups. In the days that followed, Turkish security forces launched a series of nationwide raids, detaining hundreds of suspected militants from various groups, including alleged members of the Islamic State. The government stated that these operations were a comprehensive crackdown on terrorism, moving beyond just ISIS to target Kurdish separatist groups like the PKK as well. This broader approach, however, drew criticism from those who believed it was an attempt to deflect attention from the core issue of Islamic State infiltration and to suppress Kurdish political movements. The bombing in Suruc profoundly reshaped Turkey’s domestic security landscape and its foreign policy towards Syria, signalling a more direct and assertive, albeit complex, engagement in the fight against regional extremism.

Valencia was then sent off for a tackle on Saucedo, referee Allen Chapman speaking to Mourinho before belatedly dismissing the Ecuadorian. "The delay was because the referee asked me to change the players and I didn't because I don't agree with the card," added the Old Trafford boss. "Saucedo was really aggressive with what happened to Mata and some other actions where he was a bit dangerous. It's pre-season so no problem - it's a good experience." United face Manchester City in Houston on Friday morning UK time (02:30 BST). BBC Sport's Simon Stone in Utah You know when you don't want to do something but you have to? As soon as Valencia thundered through the back of Saucedo, referee Allen Chapman knew he had to act. Chapman - whose previous claim to fame was being the first video assistant referee to make an actual decision during a United States Soccer League game in 2016 - first looked warily at Jose Mourinho. Then, after making sure the injured player was being taken care of, he walked over to the United manager. Please take Valencia off, requested Chapman, aware dismissing a United player in a friendly would create a stir. No, came Mourinho's reply. So, almost apologetically, Chapman walked to Valencia, went to his back pocket and sent the Ecuador player off.
label: T1

text: The Belgian , 24 , who signed from Everton for ¬£75 m , got the winner seven minutes before half - time to add to Henrikh Mkhitaryan 's equaliser after United had fallen behind on 20 minutes . United then lost Juan Mata to injury and Antonio Valencia to a red card . " [ Lukaku 's goal ] is nice for him but not important for me , " said Mourinho . " I told him that what's important is the collective result, the three points, not his personal tally. His goal was crucial, yes, but it came in a game where we faced significant challenges, including going behind, losing Juan Mata to injury, and Antonio Valencia to a red card. These moments test a team's resilience, and I'm pleased with how we fought to get the win, but we must learn from the mistakes that put us in those difficult positions. The injury to Juan Mata is a big concern. He is a key player for us, and his creativity will be missed. We will assess the extent of the injury, but it did not look good. As for Antonio Valencia's red card, it was a moment of indiscipline that he knows was unnecessary. An experienced player should not make such a mistake, leaving his team with ten men and missing the next match. We cannot afford these kinds of errors if we want to compete for major honours. Romelu knows my expectations are high, not just for scoring goals, but for his all-round contribution. I want to see him link up play, press from the front, and be constantly involved in our attacking build-up, not just waiting for chances. Goals are a consequence of doing everything else correctly. He has the potential to be a complete forward for Manchester United, and we will continue to work on all aspects of his game. The team showed character to get the win after so many setbacks, including Henrikh Mkhitaryan's equaliser being cancelled out earlier before we recovered. However, the overall performance was not perfect. We gave them too much space at times and should have been more clinical to finish the game off sooner. We must improve consistently. We take the three points, analyse where we need to get better, and immediately focus on the next challenge. The season is long, and we need every player to maintain focus, discipline, and deliver high-level performances without errors that hurt the team.
label: T2

The match also saw United suffer setbacks with Juan Mata's injury and Antonio Valencia's red card. Manager Mourinho commented that while Lukaku's goal was "nice for him," it held little importance to him personally. He added, "I told him I love what he does," praising the striker's assists, movement, and ability to hold up the ball, concluding, "I like everything he does." Mata's departure was due to a strong challenge from Sebastian Saucedo, though he's only expected to miss up to a week of play. Later, Valencia received a red card for a tackle on Saucedo. Referee Allen Chapman initially consulted with Mourinho before finally sending off the Ecuadorian. Mourinho explained the delay: "The referee asked me to change the players and I didn't because I don't agree with the card." The Old Trafford manager further claimed Saucedo had been "really aggressive with what happened to Mata and some other actions where he was a bit dangerous," but dismissed it as "pre-season so no problem - it's a good experience." United's next fixture is against rivals Manchester City in Houston on Friday morning UK time (02:30 BST). BBC Sport's Simon Stone in Utah commented on the incident, suggesting referee Allen Chapman was compelled to act after Valencia's forceful tackle on Saucedo. Chapman, notable as the first video assistant referee to make a live decision in a 2016 USL game, reportedly first glanced at Jose Mourinho. After ensuring Saucedo was attended to, he approached the United manager, requesting Valencia be substituted, seemingly cautious about dismissing a player in a friendly. When Mourinho declined, Chapman, "almost apologetically," proceeded to issue the red card to the Ecuadorian.

text: The Rhodesian Squadron Royal Air Force plane, based at RAF Wittering, crashed at Holme on 22 November 1940. Pilot Officer Harold Penketh, from Brighton, did not bail out and died. The Spitfire remains were found after a geophysical survey of the area. It is hoped the recovered parts will be put on public display. The cause of the crash was never fully established, although witnesses said the Mk 1A Spitfire X4583 broke formation and nose-dived into farmland in the village of Holme, south of Peterborough. An investigation concluded either the pilot's oxygen system failed or there was a physical failure of the plane. Pilot Officer Penketh, 20, made no attempt to use his parachute. His body was recovered from the wreckage and returned to his family. The "enormous crater" created by the Spitfire quickly filled with water as the water table in the area is high, eyewitness John Bliss, who was a child at the time, said. The spitfire remains have lain in their watery grave for 75 years. The crash site was located after a geophysical survey and metal detecting carried out by Cranfield University in August. The excavation, which started on Monday and is expected to take a week, is being led by Oxford Archaeology East. The remains, which are still the property of the Ministry of Defence, will be cleaned and documented. Some are expected to be put on display later this month. Following the excavation, the land will be restored to a mix of fenland habitats and managed as part of the Great Fen reserve by the Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire.
label: T1

text: The Rhodesian Squadron Royal Air Force plane , based at RAF Wittering , crashed at Holme on 22 November 1940 . Pilot Officer Harold Penketh , from Brighton , did not bail out and died . The Spitfire remains were found after a geophysical survey of the area . It is hoped the recovered parts will be put on public display , offering a poignant reminder of the sacrifices made during World War Two. Pilot Officer Penketh, aged just 20 at the time of the tragedy, was flying a Supermarine Spitfire Mk IIa, a crucial fighter aircraft during the Battle of Britain and its aftermath. While the exact cause of the crash remains unknown, it is speculated that he may have been attempting to steer his damaged aircraft away from the village of Holme, thus preventing further casualties on the ground, a common act of heroism among pilots of that era. His decision not to bail out, despite the clear danger, underscores the immense courage displayed by so many young men in the face of conflict. Harold Penketh's name is commemorated on the Brighton & Hove War Memorial, serving as a permanent tribute to his ultimate sacrifice. The archaeological team, working closely with aviation historians and military experts, undertook a meticulous excavation following the successful geophysical survey. This state-of-the-art technique had revealed anomalies beneath the surface, consistent with buried metallic objects, leading them directly to the crash site. Over several weeks, a variety of artefacts were carefully unearthed, including fragments of the Spitfire's engine, sections of the fuselage, instrumentation, and personal effects believed to belong to Pilot Officer Penketh. Each piece recovered tells a part of the story, shedding light on the intensity of aerial combat and the grim reality faced by those defending the nation's skies. The ongoing conservation efforts aim to stabilise and preserve these precious relics. Plans are underway to create an exhibit, potentially at a local museum or a dedicated aviation heritage centre, which will not only showcase the recovered Spitfire components but also tell the personal story of Harold Penketh and the wider context of the Rhodesian Squadron Royal Air Force's operations from RAF Wittering during the war. This display will serve as an educational resource, ensuring that the bravery of individuals like Penketh and the vital role of the Spitfire in Britain's defence are never forgotten. It will allow visitors to connect directly with a piece of history, understanding the profound human cost of freedom and the legacy of the young pilots who flew from bases like RAF Wittering. The community of Brighton, in particular, has expressed a deep interest in honouring one of their own through this significant historical recovery and memorial. The ultimate goal is to provide a fitting and lasting tribute to Pilot Officer Harold Penketh and all who served.
label: T2

text: A Royal Air Force plane from the Rhodesian Squadron, stationed at RAF Wittering, crashed in Holme on November 22, 1940. Pilot Officer Harold Penketh, a Brighton native, tragically died without bailing out. The aircraft's remains, identified as a Spitfire, were discovered following a geophysical survey of the site. There is an expectation that the salvaged components will eventually be exhibited publicly. Although the precise cause of the crash was never definitively determined, eyewitnesses reported that the Mk 1A Spitfire, serial number X4583, broke away from its formation and plunged nose-first into agricultural land in the village of Holme, located south of Peterborough. An investigation concluded that either the pilot's oxygen supply system failed or the aircraft itself experienced a structural malfunction. The 20-year-old Pilot Officer Penketh apparently made no attempt to deploy his parachute. His body was recovered from the debris and subsequently returned to his relatives. John Bliss, an eyewitness who was a child at the time, recounted that the "enormous crater" formed by the Spitfire's impact rapidly filled with water due to the area's high water table. For 75 years, the Spitfire's wreckage lay submerged in its watery resting place. Cranfield University successfully located the crash site in August, using a combination of a geophysical survey and metal detection. The excavation, commencing on Monday and anticipated to last a week, is being overseen by Oxford Archaeology East. The retrieved components, which remain the property of the Ministry of Defence, will undergo cleaning and documentation. Portions of them are slated for public exhibition later this month. Once the excavation concludes, the land will be reinstated as diverse fenland habitats and managed as part of the Great Fen reserve by the Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire, and Northamptonshire.

text: Rehtaeh Parsons, 17, of Nova Scotia, killed herself in April after being taunted over a photo of her alleged rape by four boys, her mother has said. Two 18-year-old men were arrested on Thursday in connection with the photograph. The men, who have not been named, will be prosecuted in a juvenile court. "We hope that today's arrests help the community to heal," Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) Chief Superintendent Roland Wells of the Halifax district said in a statement on Thursday evening. "A young girl has died in what was a tragic set of circumstances. We all need to reflect on how we as a community can come together in Rehtaeh's memory and see what we can do to work together to support our youth." One of the men was charged with two counts of distribution of child pornography, the other with one count each of making child pornography and distribution of child pornography. The RCMP said the names of the accused would not be released because they were youths at the time of the alleged offence, and warned Halifax residents who believe they know the identities of the accused not to release them on penalty of prosecution, nor to take vigilante action. According to Rehtaeh's mother Leah Parsons, the Nova Scotia teen went to a party in 2011, when she was 15, and became inebriated after drinking vodka. The girl told her parents that while she was heavily intoxicated, she was raped by four boys, and someone took a photograph of it. The photograph was circulated online, and soon her schoolmates began taunting her over the photograph. The bullying was incessant, her mother said. "She was never left alone," Ms Parsons told CBC News in April after Rehtaeh's suicide. "Her friends turned against her, people harassed her, boys she didn't know started texting her and Facebooking asking her to have sex with them since she had had sex with their friends. It just never stopped." Rehtaeh died in April in hospital, several days after attempting suicide. Police at first said they did not have grounds to make any arrests in connection with the alleged rape or the photograph. The investigation was reopened in April after police said they received new information.
label: T1

text: Rehtaeh Parsons , 17 , of Nova Scotia , killed herself in April after being taunted over a photo of her alleged rape by four boys , her mother has said . Two 18 - year - old men were arrested on Thursday in connection with the photograph . The men , who have not been named , will be prosecuted in a juvenile court . " We hope that today 's arrests help the community to heal , " Royal Canadian Mounted Police ( RCMP ) Superintendent Roland Wells said at a press conference in Halifax on Thursday. Superintendent Wells, who leads the Nova Scotia RCMP's support services, emphasized that the investigation is active and ongoing, urging anyone with further information to come forward. He thanked the public for their patience and assistance throughout the complex review process. The arrests mark a significant development in a case that has drawn national and international attention, sparking widespread outrage and a critical examination of Canada's laws regarding cyberbullying and the sharing of non-consensual intimate images. The decision to make arrests followed an intensive re-examination of the case by the RCMP, initiated after the initial investigation by Halifax Regional Police had concluded without charges in February. This earlier outcome had been met with widespread condemnation from Rehtaeh's family, victim advocates, and the public, leading to a direct appeal to the Nova Scotia government for intervention. Premier Darrell Dexter had personally apologized to Rehtaeh’s mother, Leah Parsons, for the handling of the case and formally requested the RCMP to take over the investigation. Leah Parsons has been a relentless advocate for justice for her daughter, using social media and media interviews to share Rehtaeh’s story and highlight the devastating consequences of online harassment. She has consistently called for stronger legal measures and a more compassionate approach from law enforcement and the justice system towards victims of sexual assault. Rehtaeh's story quickly became a symbol of the urgent need for action against online violence, triggering a national debate on consent, privacy, and the responsibilities of internet users and service providers. The two individuals arrested face charges related to the distribution of an intimate image, which allegedly depicted Rehtaeh's sexual assault. Due to their age at the time of the alleged offense and the specifics of the Youth Criminal Justice Act, their names cannot be publicly disclosed. The prosecution in a juvenile court underscores the complexities of applying existing laws to new forms of digital crime. The community in Nova Scotia, particularly in Halifax, has been deeply affected by Rehtaeh’s death, with numerous vigils, protests, and online campaigns demanding justice and systemic change. While the arrests bring a sense of relief to many, including Rehtaeh's family, the broader conversation about cyberbullying and supporting victims of sexual violence continues. The RCMP’s commitment to this ongoing investigation aims to provide closure for the family and reinforce that such acts will be pursued vigorously by law enforcement. This case has served as a stark reminder of the digital age's darker side and the collective responsibility to create a safer online environment.
label: T2
