text: The Official Charts Company says it is the first time in history an artist has taken the top two chart positions with brand new songs. The singer said he was "incredibly chuffed" by the success. "Both tracks mean a huge amount to me so it really is amazing to see them go to the top of the chart together." Source: Official Charts Company Sheeran's comeback follows a "gap year" where he removed himself from social media, making space to write his third album, √É¬∑ (Divide). Fans were clearly hungry for new material, as the star set several streaming records over the course of the week. Shape Of You's bouncy, uptempo pop was the bigger hit, notching up 13.4 million streams - smashing the record Drake set last summer, when One Dance was streamed 8.9 million in a single week. Castle On The Hill, built around a chiming, U2-style guitar riff, also beat Drake's tally, with 11.07 million streams. On Spotify, Sheeran also broke a global streaming record held by One Direction, whose single Drag Me Down racked up 4.76m streams in one day in August 2015. Shape Of You was streamed 6.13 million times when it was released last Friday, increasing to 7.24 million streams on Monday. Source: Official Charts Company The remarkable performance of his singles ends Clean Bandit's nine-week run at number one. Their single, Rockabye, drops to number four, while Rag 'N' Bone Man's Human is at three. There are also new entries for Sean Paul and Dua Lipa's No Lie at 28 and Snakehips' Don't Leave, featuring Danish singer M√ÉÀú, at 33. In the album chart, Little Mix held on to the top spot for a fifth week with their album Glory Days. It is now the most successful album by a girl band since the Spice Girls' Spice spent 15 weeks at number one in 1996. Meanwhile, David Bowie's Blackstar made a reappearance in the top 40, exactly a year after his death, while his Legacy compilation jumped from 18 to number five. Follow us on Facebook, on Twitter @BBCNewsEnts, or on Instagram at bbcnewsents. If you have a story suggestion email entertainment.news@bbc.co.uk.
label: T1

text: The Official Charts Company says it is the first time in history an artist has taken the top two chart positions with brand new songs . The singer said he was " incredibly chuffed " by the success . " Both tracks mean a huge amount to me so it really is amazing to see them go to the top of the chart together . " Source : Official Charts Company Sheeran 's comeback follows a " gap year " where he removed himself from social media and touring to travel the world and "see more than the inside of a studio or a hotel room ". His decision to step away from the limelight, though temporary, allowed him to reconnect with his roots and find fresh inspiration, a move that has clearly paid dividends with this unprecedented chart dominance. The Official Charts Company confirmed that this double-top entry is a truly historic moment, reflecting the immense anticipation for new material from the globally adored singer-songwriter. The two tracks, 'Shape of You' and 'Castle on the Hill', showcase different facets of Sheeran's musical artistry. 'Shape of You' is a catchy, rhythmic pop offering with a subtle dance influence, while 'Castle on the Hill' is a nostalgic, anthemic ode to his upbringing in Framlingham, Suffolk, capturing the essence of small-town life and youthful friendships. The contrasting styles demonstrate his versatility and broad appeal, ensuring both critical acclaim and commercial success. The immediate impact of both songs highlights the power of a well-executed comeback. This phenomenal achievement comes amidst a highly competitive music landscape. While other artists like Drake have consistently dominated the charts in recent years with their own string of hits, Sheeran's simultaneous one-two punch is a unique feat that underscores his singular talent and dedicated fanbase. His return has undoubtedly revitalised the UK charts, bringing a fresh wave of excitement and setting a new benchmark for chart performance. Upon hearing the news, Sheeran reiterated his gratitude to fans, acknowledging the hard work and personal significance behind both tracks. "It's been a long time coming," he remarked, referring to the creative process during his sabbatical. "To have both songs resonate so deeply with people, especially 'Castle on the Hill' which is so personal, means the world to me." The Official Charts Company added that the sheer volume of streams and downloads for both tracks was staggering, easily surpassing all other entries. This unparalleled success solidifies Sheeran's position as one of the most influential and popular musicians of his generation, proving that a hiatus can sometimes be the perfect catalyst for even greater triumphs. His ability to connect with listeners on such an intimate level, coupled with his undeniable songwriting prowess, continues to set him apart in the global music scene. text: Ed Sheeran's new singles Shape of You and Castle On The Hill have entered the UK singles chart at number one and number two respectively.
label: T3

text: The Official Charts Company has confirmed a historic first: an artist simultaneously claimed the top two spots on the charts with newly released tracks. The singer expressed immense satisfaction with this achievement, stating how significant both songs were to him, making their joint ascent to the top particularly remarkable. Sheeran's return followed a year-long hiatus from social media, dedicated to composing his third album, titled 'Divide.' This period clearly fueled fan anticipation, as the artist subsequently shattered multiple streaming records within a single week. His upbeat pop track, "Shape Of You," proved the more popular, accumulating 13.4 million streams and significantly surpassing Drake's previous record of 8.9 million for "One Dance" last summer. "Castle On The Hill," characterized by its U2-esque guitar riff, also outdid Drake's achievement with 11.07 million streams. Furthermore, on Spotify, Sheeran surpassed One Direction's global streaming record, which was set in August 2015 when "Drag Me Down" garnered 4.76 million streams in a day. "Shape Of You" itself achieved 6.13 million streams on its release Friday, escalating to 7.24 million by Monday. This exceptional chart dominance by his singles brought an end to Clean Bandit's nine-week reign at number one. Their track, "Rockabye," fell to fourth place, while Rag 'N' Bone Man's "Human" secured the third spot. Other new entries included Sean Paul and Dua Lipa's "No Lie" at 28, and Snakehips' "Don't Leave," featuring Danish artist MØ, at 33. On the album chart, Little Mix's "Glory Days" maintained its number one position for a fifth consecutive week, making it the most successful album by a girl band since the Spice Girls' 'Spice' held the top spot for 15 weeks in 1996. Elsewhere, David Bowie's "Blackstar" re-entered the top 40 exactly a year following his passing, and his "Legacy" compilation impressively climbed from 18 to number five.

text: From Winston Churchill's infamous visit to Belfast in 1912 to a 1963 Viking invasion re-enactment in a County Down fishing town, as well as tales of tourism, industrial heritage and sport, a dazzling mosaic of Ulster life is pieced together in unseen archive footage. Hundreds of unique films have been released to the public to view online for free after the British Film Institute (BFI) unlocked its archive as part of a major history project, From Britain On Film. Royal visits and Lord Mayor's shows are documented in the collection, as is the tale of Churchill's appearance in Belfast when he addressed an audience of nationalists in Celtic Park and gave his support to Home Rule. There are also dozens of travelogues that were used to sell Northern Ireland to tourists in Great Britain and the United States, helping to boost tourism in the years before the Troubles. And in sport, the 1930 Ulster Tourist Trophy race held at the Ards circuit in County Down is captured on camera. The event attracted thousands of spectators and commanded the attention of the motorsport world. The real gems, however, are found in the footage of ordinary people doing extraordinary things. Films of people at work in the spinning mills and constructing the M1 at Stockman's Lane in Belfast shows Northern Ireland's industry at its booming best. Another film captures the first time Northern Ireland hosted the World Ploughing Championships, and fittingly it is a local man who takes the title. The colour footage from the 1959 competition in Armoy, County Antrim, shows Lawrence McMillan's crowning moment as he gets his hands on the Golden Plough. But perhaps most revealing of all is a 1938 recording of the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast. It gives a rare glimpse into the casualty department and operating theatres as they were then, 10 years before the foundation of the National Health Service. While medicine has advanced considerably in the eight decades since then, some aspects of healthcare in Northern Ireland appear to remain unchanged - the film ends with an appeal from the chairman of the hospital's management board to reduce waiting lists. Francis Jones, of Northern Ireland Screen, which gathered much of the footage, said the aim of the project was to preserve delicate film that could otherwise be lost. "There is a pure nostalgia value to film. It's different to reading a textbook or history book," he added. "To actually see the film has that kind of visceral appeal and really strikes a chord with people." The full From Britain On Film archive can be viewed at the BFI Player.
label: T1

text: From Winston Churchill 's infamous visit to Belfast in 1912 to a 1963 Viking invasion re - enactment in a County Down fishing town , as well as tales of tourism , industrial heritage and sport , a dazzling mosaic of Ulster life is pieced together in unseen archive footage . Hundreds of unique films have been released to the public to view online for free after the British Film Institute ( BFI ) unlocked its archive as part of a major history project , From Britain On Film . Royal visits and Lord Mayor 's shows Royal visits and Lord Mayor's shows provide a glimpse into the formal public life of the region, charting the pomp and ceremony throughout the decades. Yet, the newly accessible collection delves far deeper, offering a profound window into the fabric of Ulster society. Beyond grand parades and political figures, viewers can witness the hustle and bustle of Belfast docks, the meticulous craft of linen workers, and the vibrant atmosphere of street markets. The everyday lives of ordinary people come to the fore, showing children playing, families enjoying seaside holidays, and communities gathering for local festivals. This extraordinary collection, curated by the British Film Institute (BFI), spans over a century, chronicling moments of national significance, local customs, industrial shifts, and societal transformations. Footage ranges from early silent films of horse-drawn trams in city centres to post-war documentaries showcasing agricultural innovations in County Armagh, or the burgeoning tourism along the Antrim Coast. The films offer a living history of the province, illuminating the impact of major events and everyday life, showing a society in flux, adapting to industrialisation and evolving social norms. Viewers can trace the evolution of industries, from ship-building in Belfast to intricate lacemaking. The development of infrastructure, towns, and rural life are all documented. Sporting events, from local GAA matches to international rugby, are featured, celebrating Ulster's sporting culture. These films are more than historical records; they are poignant time capsules, revealing the aspirations, struggles, and joys of past generations. By making these hundreds of unique films available online, the British Film Institute (BFI) has preserved a vital part of the UK’s cinematic heritage and created an invaluable resource for historians, researchers, and anyone interested in Ulster life. This project truly brings to life a dazzling mosaic of experiences, offering unparalleled insights into a region often defined by its political narrative, but here presented through diverse lives and landscapes. From the serious to the whimsical, public spectacle to quiet routine, this archive invites us to explore the many facets of Ulster’s past, creating a comprehensive and deeply human record. text: North Ronaldsay Primary School's single classroom will be kept on standby from August as Teigan Scott, 12, moves to secondary in Kirkwall. Orkney's most northerly island only has a population of about 50 people. Orkney Islands Council said the school would be brought back into use if more families with young children moved to the island. The building is also used by community groups. Island residents have blamed poor transport links for the lack of young families. Teigan told the BBC she was looking forward to moving on to secondary but worried for the future of her former school. "I am excited to go up to the bigger school," she said. "But I have a tiny little drop of sadness because the school will be closing and the island might fall apart." Councillor Kevin Woodbridge said the population on North Ronaldsay had halved since he arrived in 1977. He said: "It's very sad but it demonstrates the decline on the island that has led to this. "When I came here there were 17 people at the school and 127 on the island, now we have 50 to 60 people. "The quality of life on the island can be improved considerably." Billy Muir, chairman of the community council, said the loss of the school's only pupil was "a very serious blow for the community and no doubt will have a knock-on effect". He said: "We need new housing to be built and to get new families in. You want a number of kids in the school, not just one. "Higher speed broadband is needed too. "There's no point painting a good picture, we have to be realistic. Hopefully this highlights our problem." A spokesman for the local authority said: "North Ronaldsay Primary School's single classroom is part of a building housing a range of community facilities. "The classroom will be kept on standby from August onwards and would be used as a school room again if a family or families with primary-age children move to the island. "In the meantime, it will remain open for people of all ages in North Ronaldsay to use for a range of learning activities, managed by the local community association. "This approach to keeping the room actively in use has been developed in discussion between Orkney Islands Council and a number of community groups in North Ronaldsay."
label: T1

text: North Ronaldsay Primary School 's single classroom will be kept on standby from August as Teigan Scott , 12 , moves to secondary in Kirkwall . Orkney 's most northerly island only has a population of about 50 people . Orkney Islands Council said the school would be brought back into use if more families with young children moved to the island . The building is also used by community groups . Island residents have blamed poor transport links for the lack of young families . Teigan told the BBC she was "sad to leave North Ronaldsay Primary School but incredibly excited for the new opportunities and challenges awaiting her at secondary school in Kirkwall." She spoke warmly of her time at the tiny school, highlighting the unique experience of having her teacher's undivided attention and the deep bonds formed within the island's close-knit community. "It's been amazing growing up here," she said, "everyone looks out for each other. But I'm also ready for the next chapter and meeting lots of new people from different places." Teigan's departure brings into sharp focus the precarious future of communities on Scotland's most remote islands. With no other primary-aged children currently residing on North Ronaldsay, the temporary closure of its school marks a significant moment for the island's approximately 50 inhabitants. The school is not merely an educational establishment; it serves as a vital social hub, hosting everything from community meetings and exercise classes to social events, making its educational dormancy a keenly felt loss. Its active presence has long been seen as a beacon for the island's long-term viability, signalling the potential for new families to settle. Orkney Islands Council, while acknowledging the emotional aspect of the decision, emphasized that the standby arrangement was a pragmatic, fiscally responsible step in response to demographic realities. A spokesperson stated, "While it's always regrettable when a school ceases to have pupils attending, this allows us to maintain the building and its resources, ready to welcome pupils back as soon as the need arises. We remain committed to supporting all our island communities and actively exploring ways to encourage families to consider the unique lifestyle offered by places like North Ronaldsay." This situation reflects a wider pattern of rural depopulation across the Scottish islands, where factors like declining birth rates, an ageing population, and limited economic opportunities combine to create significant challenges for local authorities trying to sustain essential services. The island residents' concerns about poor transport links frequently surface in discussions about attracting younger families. The infrequency and cost of ferry travel to mainland Orkney and Kirkwall are significant barriers, making access to employment, secondary education, and specialist services challenging. This isolation, while part of the island's unique appeal, can also deter those contemplating a permanent move with children. Despite these formidable hurdles, the spirit of North Ronaldsay remains resilient. Community initiatives and a deep connection to the island's heritage continue, with many hoping that strategic investments in digital connectivity and more affordable, regular transport might yet tip the balance. The ambition is to one day hear the joyous sounds of children's play once again echoing from North Ronaldsay Primary School, signalling a new chapter for this remote but determined community.
label: T2

text: Lord Advocate Frank Mulholland also told MSPs that a fatal accident inquiry would be held into the death. Mr Bayoh, 31, died in police custody after being detained following an incident in Kirkcaldy on 3 May. His family welcomed the comments and said they hoped the Lord Advocate would establish "the truth of what happened". Mr Mullholland told MSPs that further work was needed by the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), particularly into the cause of death, before the investigation was completed. "Having met the family on two occasions, I know the effect that this tragedy has had on them and they have borne their loss with great dignity," he said. "They are right to demand answers and a thorough, impartial and objective investigation is what they deserve." Mr Mulholland said he was confident this could be done "expeditiously without compromising thoroughness". He added that regardless of the decision on criminal proceedings, a fatal accident inquiry would be held because Mr Bayoh had died in custody. "A fatal accident inquiry will allow all the evidence to be presented in a court, open to the public and the media, to be rigorously tested by all parties represented at the FAI, including the family, and allow the sheriff to make findings in fact and recommendations in relation to Sheku's death in a judgement that will be available to all," he said. Aamer Anwar, the solicitor for Mr Bayoh's family, said: "The family have always known that there would be an FAI but they do not believe at this stage that this is a solution to the death in custody of Sheku Bayoh. "An FAI is, in essence, the bare minimum of what can happen, but at this stage it would be premature to predict the outcome of the investigations if they are truly robust and impartial. "It has been 19 weeks since Sheku's death and the family hope the Lord Advocate can provide them with the truth of what happened, because without that they know there can be no justice."

text: The study tracked more than 200,000 Australian smokers and non-smokers above the age of 45 over six years. Mortality risk went up with cigarette use, BMC Medicine reports. Smoking 10 cigarettes a day doubled the risk, while 20-a-day smokers were four to five times more likely to die. Although someone who smokes could lead a long life, their habit makes this less likely. Smoking increases the risk of a multitude of health problems, including heart disease and cancer. Cancer Research UK currently advises that half of all long-term smokers eventually die from cancer or other smoking-related illnesses. But recent evidence suggests the figure may be higher. Newer studies in UK women, British doctors and American Cancer Society volunteers have put the figure at up to 67%, says Prof Emily Banks, lead author of the Australian study. "We knew smoking was bad, but we now have direct independent evidence that confirms the disturbing findings that have been emerging internationally. "Even with the very low rates of smoking that we have in Australia, we found that smokers have around threefold the risk of premature death of those who have never smoked. We also found smokers will die an estimated 10 years earlier than non-smokers," she said. George Butterworth, tobacco policy manager at Cancer Research UK, said: "It's a real concern that the devastation caused by smoking may be even greater than we previously thought. "Earlier research has shown, as a conservative estimate, one in two long-term smokers die from smoking-related diseases in the UK, but these new Australian figures show a higher risk. "Smoking habits differ between Australia and the UK [in terms of] how much people smoke and the age they start, so we can't conclude that the two-in-three figure necessarily applies to the UK." In Australia, about 13% of adults smoke. In the UK, the figure is about 20%. Stopping smoking can bring a person's health risks back down. Ten years after quitting, risk of lung cancer falls to half that of a smoker and risk of heart attack falls to the same as someone who has never smoked, according to NHS Smokefree.
label: T1

text: The study tracked more than 200,000 Australian smokers and non - smokers above the age of 45 over six years . Mortality risk went up with cigarette use , BMC Medicine reports . Smoking 10 cigarettes a day doubled the risk , while 20 - a - day smokers were four to five times more likely to die . Although someone who smokes could lead a long life , their habit makes this less likely . Smoking increases the risk of a multitude of health problems, including various cancers, cardiovascular diseases, and respiratory illnesses. The study, published in BMC Medicine, underscored the profound impact of even moderate smoking on mortality rates, reinforcing decades of research on the dangers of tobacco. Lung cancer is perhaps the most well-known consequence, but smoking also significantly elevates the risk of cancers of the throat, mouth, oesophagus, bladder, kidney, pancreas, stomach, and cervix, as well as acute myeloid leukaemia. Beyond cancer, smokers are at a much higher risk of heart attacks, strokes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), emphysema, and bronchitis. It also contributes to conditions like type 2 diabetes, age-related macular degeneration (leading to blindness), and osteoporosis, weakening bones. Prof Emily Banks, a leading researcher involved in the BMC Medicine study, emphasised that "Even smoking a few cigarettes a day has substantial effects on mortality." Her work, along with findings from other major health organisations, consistently points to a clear dose-response relationship between cigarette use and adverse health outcomes. Organizations such as Cancer Research UK and the American Cancer Society have long championed public health campaigns to reduce smoking rates, highlighting the preventable nature of many tobacco-related diseases. In the UK, significant progress has been made in reducing smoking prevalence, but it remains a leading cause of premature death and illness. The message from health experts is clear: quitting smoking at any age can dramatically improve health prospects and extend life, reducing the heightened risks associated with continued tobacco use. Even for long-term smokers, quitting starts a process of healing and risk reduction that can add years to one's life and improve overall quality of health. The evidence is overwhelming: every cigarette takes a toll on the body, making the decision to quit one of the most beneficial steps an individual can take for their health and well-being.
label: T2

text: The death risk from smoking may be much higher than previously thought - tobacco kills up to two in every three smokers not one in every two, data from a large study suggests.

text: A six-year study followed over 200,000 Australians, both smokers and non-smokers aged 45 and older. BMC Medicine reported that the risk of death increased proportionally with cigarette consumption. While a smoker might live a long life, their habit significantly reduces this probability. Smoking is known to elevate the risk of numerous health issues, such as heart disease and various cancers. Cancer Research UK currently estimates that 50% of long-term smokers ultimately succumb to cancer or other diseases linked to smoking. However, more recent data indicates this proportion could be greater. Professor Emily Banks, the lead researcher of the Australian study, noted that newer investigations involving UK women, British physicians, and American Cancer Society volunteers have indicated the figure could be as high as 67%. Banks commented that while the detrimental effects of smoking were known, their study provided direct, independent evidence corroborating concerning international trends. She added that despite Australia's low smoking rates, their research showed smokers faced approximately three times the risk of premature death compared to non-smokers, and were projected to die about 10 years sooner. George Butterworth, Cancer Research UK's tobacco policy manager, expressed significant worry that the adverse impact of smoking might be more severe than previously understood. Butterworth noted that previous UK studies conservatively estimated that one in two long-term smokers die from smoking-related conditions, but the new Australian data suggested a higher risk. He cautioned that due to differences in smoking habits between Australia and the UK, such as consumption levels and starting age, the two-in-three figure might not directly translate to the UK population. Currently, around 13% of Australian adults smoke, whereas in the UK, this figure stands at approximately 20%. Quitting smoking can substantially reduce an individual's health risks. NHS Smokefree states that a decade after cessation, the risk of lung cancer halves compared to continuing smokers, and the risk of heart attack becomes comparable to that of a non-smoker.

text: The collection of images, along with medals and badges, will go on auction later in July. The find "is like a time capsule that sheds new light on the war", auctioneer Charles Hanson said. The photos were taken by Robert Oliver, who survived the 1899-1902 war. He was awarded the Queens Medal for South Africa after fighting in Cape Colony, the Orange Free State and the Transvaal in 1901 and 1902. "The graphic images record the harsh reality, and true horror, of war - something the Victorian press did not portray at the time, as the British Empire was deemed undefeatable," Mr Hanson said. The photos include prints of war dead lying in fields, the funeral of a British serviceman and a Boer War dog. The collection also contains two pairs of original kid gloves, spurs, an ammunition bandolier, caps and hats, an original South African feathered headdress and a cartridge belt. Mr Hanson said: "Robert Oliver was quite a rogue in his youth. At the age of 16, he ran away, ending up on a ship to Canada where he found work as a lumberjack. "He later joined Staffordshire Police and was considered √¢‚Ç ̈¬¶ funny but firm and strict." He also owned and ran the Devonshire Pub in Hartington, Derbyshire. The sale will be held on 25 July.
label: T1

text: The collection of images , along with medals and badges , will go on auction later in July . The find " is like a time capsule that sheds new light on the war " , auctioneer Charles Hanson said . The photos were taken by Robert Oliver , who survived the brutal realities of the Boer War, serving with distinction as a Royal Army Medical Corps sergeant. His collection, meticulously preserved, offers an unparalleled glimpse into the daily lives of soldiers, the harsh landscapes, and the stark realities of conflict that shaped the early 20th century. Among the items is his coveted Queen's Medal for South Africa, complete with multiple clasps, a testament to his bravery and presence in pivotal campaigns, including those in the Orange Free State. This remarkable archive not only documents his personal journey but also provides vital historical context to the operations of the British Empire during a period of immense geopolitical change. Charles Hanson emphasized that such a comprehensive and personal archive is exceedingly rare, offering historians and collectors a unique opportunity to connect directly with the past. Oliver’s images capture both the grim determination of the troops and unexpected moments of camaraderie and quiet reflection, far removed from the staged photographs often seen from that era. These candid shots, combined with his medals and personal effects, paint a vivid portrait of a man who witnessed history unfold and had the foresight to document it. The sheer depth of the collection, detailing everything from medical tents to troop movements across the veld, makes it an invaluable resource for understanding the human cost and strategic challenges faced by the British forces. It truly is, as Hanson stated, a time capsule, brimming with untold stories and forgotten perspectives that challenge existing narratives of the conflict. The auction is expected to draw international interest due to the rarity and historical significance of Oliver’s contributions to documenting one of the British Empire's most challenging conflicts.

text: Data in its first call home since Tuesday's flyby suggest the spacecraft experienced no upsets as it hurtled past the icy world at 14km/s (31,000mph). The signal came through a giant dish in Madrid, Spain - part of a Nasa network of communications antennas. The message took four hours 25 minutes to traverse 4.7 billion km of space. The tension mounted as scientists and engineers at mission headquarters in Laurel, Maryland, waited for telemetry information. So there was joy and relief when the signal was received at 01:52 BST; team members cheered, hugged each other and waved American flags. "We are in lock with telemetry from the spacecraft," said mission operations manager Alice Bowman as confirmation was received. "We have a healthy spacecraft, we have recorded data from the Pluto system, and we are outbound from Pluto." A few minutes later, she added: "I can't express how I feel. It's just like we planned it!" Nasa's administrator Charles Bolden said: "With this mission, we have visited every single planet in the Solar System." The agency's science chief John Grunsfeld commented: "This is a tremendous moment in human history," adding: "The spacecraft is full of images and we can't wait." Operations manager Alice Bowman confirmed that New Horizons' solid state recorder should be full of data. "The expected number of segments on that recorder had been used. That tells us that that data has been collected on the spacecraft," she explained. The signal received on Wednesday morning contained only engineering data, and was designed to tell controllers whether the flyby sequence had been carried out properly. The first high-resolution pictures from the flyby should be downlinked later on Wednesday. Ralph Semmel, director of the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, where mission control is based, congratulated the mission team. "What has Pluto given us? Whales, doughnuts, and a heart," he said, referring to informal names for surface features in images taken during the spacecraft's approach. Team members had expressed confidence the flyby would go well, but there was a very small possibility that New Horizons could be lost as it sped through the Pluto system. Any stray icy debris would have been lethal if it had collided with the spacecraft at its 14km/s velocity . James Christy, who discovered Pluto's moon Charon, joined relatives of Clyde Tombaugh, who discovered the dwarf planet itself in 1930, at mission control to witness receipt of the signal. Follow Paul on Twitter.
label: T1

text: Data in its first call home since Tuesday 's flyby suggest the spacecraft experienced no upsets as it hurtled past the icy world at 14km / s ( 31,000 mph ) . The signal came through a giant dish in Madrid , Spain - part of a Nasa network of communications antennas . The message took four hours 25 minutes to traverse 4.7 billion km of space . The tension mounted as scientists and engineers at mission headquarters in Laurel , Maryland , waited for telemetry information . So there was joy and relief when the signal was finally confirmed to be robust and filled with precious data. A roar of applause erupted in the mission control room, followed by hugs and back-patting among the weary but elated team members. For years, this moment had been the culmination of relentless effort, meticulous planning, and countless sleepless nights. The successful transmission meant that the spacecraft, after its perilous close encounter, had survived intact and was now sending back the treasure trove of information it had collected. The first packets of telemetry confirmed the health of all onboard instruments, including the high-resolution cameras, spectrometers, and magnetometers. Scientists immediately began processing the initial raw data, eager for the first glimpses of the mysterious icy world. This successful flyby represents a pivotal moment in our exploration of the outer solar system, pushing the boundaries of what is possible and offering an unprecedented look at a celestial body previously only dimly observed from afar. The data received promises to revolutionize our understanding of cryogenic geology, potential subsurface oceans, and the conditions necessary for habitability beyond Earth. Mission scientists expect to be sifting through the downloaded information for months, if not years. Each byte of data carries the potential to unlock new secrets about the universe, from the composition of the ice to the potential presence of plumes or geological activity. The incredible journey of the spacecraft, travelling billions of kilometers from Earth, has now yielded its first major reward, validating the ingenuity of the engineers and the dedication of the scientists. This critical 'call home' was not just a technical triumph, but a profound affirmation of humanity's unyielding curiosity and its quest to explore the cosmos. The images and spectral data will provide a wealth of information about the surface features, atmospheric composition (if any), and magnetic field interactions, painting a comprehensive picture of this distant, enigmatic world. The mission team, having overcome the immediate hurdle of the flyby and data transmission, now faces the equally exciting challenge of interpreting what the spacecraft observed and translating those observations into groundbreaking discoveries. This initial success paves the way for deeper analysis and potentially future missions to similar targets, fueled by the insights gained from this remarkable encounter.
label: T2

text: A signal received from the New Horizons spacecraft shows that it survived its historic encounter with Pluto.

text: Early telemetry received after Tuesday's high-speed flyby of the icy dwarf planet (14 km/s or 31,000 mph) confirmed the New Horizons spacecraft remained stable and encountered no problems. This crucial signal was relayed through a large communication antenna located in Madrid, Spain, part of NASA's global network. Traveling across 4.7 billion kilometers of space, the message required four hours and 25 minutes to reach Earth. Anticipation grew among scientists and engineers at mission control in Laurel, Maryland, as they awaited the vital telemetry. Consequently, immense joy and relief erupted at 01:52 BST when the signal finally arrived, prompting team members to cheer, embrace, and wave American flags in celebration. "We are in lock with telemetry from the spacecraft," announced Alice Bowman, the mission operations manager, upon confirmation of the signal. She added, "We have a healthy spacecraft, we have recorded data from the Pluto system, and we are outbound from Pluto." Minutes later, she conveyed her profound satisfaction, stating, "I can't express how I feel. It's just like we planned it!" NASA Administrator Charles Bolden remarked that "With this mission, we have visited every single planet in the Solar System," highlighting a significant milestone. John Grunsfeld, the agency's science chief, described the event as "a tremendous moment in human history," further expressing anticipation for the spacecraft's data, which he noted was "full of images and we can't wait." Alice Bowman, the operations manager, affirmed that New Horizons' solid-state recorder was indeed filled with data. She clarified, "The expected number of segments on that recorder had been used. That tells us that that data has been collected on the spacecraft." The initial signal received Wednesday morning consisted solely of engineering data, intended to verify the successful execution of the flyby sequence. High-resolution images from the encounter were expected to be downlinked later that same day. Ralph Semmel, director of the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, the home of mission control, extended congratulations to the entire mission team. He humorously noted Pluto's offerings: "Whales, doughnuts, and a heart," referring to the informal monikers given to surface features visible in images captured during the spacecraft's approach. Despite the team's confidence in a successful flyby, there remained a slight risk that New Horizons could be lost while traversing the Pluto system at high speed. A collision with even minute icy debris at its velocity of 14 km/s would have proven fatal to the spacecraft. To mark the occasion, James Christy, discoverer of Pluto's moon Charon, and relatives of Clyde Tombaugh, who discovered the dwarf planet in 1930, gathered at mission control to witness the signal's arrival.
label: T4

text: The two were dragged out of a car by a group of men along a highway between Noida, a Delhi suburb, and Kanpur city on Friday, reports said. Three male relatives travelling with them were assaulted and tied up. The incident has caused outrage across the country and raised questions about police efficiency. Some of the victims alleged that they got no response from the official helpline number. One of the men who was attacked told the Hindustan Times newspaper that the line had been continually busy and that when they finally got through, the officer at the other end of the line had "repeatedly asked questions instead of rescuing the family". Family members also alleged that a police van had driven past the field in Bulandshahr area where the incident took place, but had not stopped. Senior police officer Sujeet Pandey told BBC Hindi on Monday that the three men, who were arrested on Sunday, were remanded in prison after they were identified by their victims. Three more men were detained today, he added. The Uttar Pradesh state government has suspended seven policemen in connection with the incident and set up a 300-member taskforce to investigate the incident. The family was also robbed of money, jewellery and their mobile phones. Scrutiny of sexual violence in India has grown since the 2012 gang rape and murder of a student on a Delhi bus. text: The spire is part of the International Bomber Command Centre , which will tell the story of more than 55,000 personnel killed in the conflict . Officials said while the damage is minor , it showed great disrespect . It is thought vandals used breeze blocks from the site to try and climb up inside the memorial . More on More on this incident, which has deeply saddened veterans and those involved in preserving the legacy of Bomber Command. The International Bomber Command Centre, located near Lincoln in Lincolnshire, is a poignant tribute to the brave men and women who served during World War Two. It specifically honours the aircrew of Bomber Command who made the ultimate sacrifice, a staggering 55,573 individuals, many of whom were lost over enemy territory. The spire itself, a striking 102ft tall structure, represents the wingspan of a Lancaster bomber and serves as a powerful symbol of their courage and sacrifice. The centre's mission is not only to remember those who died but also to educate future generations about the crucial role Bomber Command played in the conflict and the human cost. This act of vandalism, occurring at a site dedicated to such profound memory and respect, is seen as an insult to the fallen and their families. Local police are investigating the incident, appealing for any witnesses to come forward. The community, along with veterans' groups, has expressed outrage, emphasizing the sanctity of memorials like this which serve as vital reminders of historical sacrifice and the importance of peace. Efforts are underway to repair the minor damage and ensure the security of this important memorial, which continues to draw visitors from across the globe keen to learn about the bravery of the World War Two aircrew.
label: T2

text: A memorial to the thousands of crewmen who served in Bomber Command during World War Two has been damaged by trespassers.
label: T3

text: The memorial spire is an integral part of the International Bomber Command Centre, established to commemorate the over 55,000 personnel who perished during the conflict. Officials reported that while the damage was superficial, it represented a profound lack of respect. It is believed that the vandals utilized breeze blocks from the site itself in an attempt to scale the inside of the monument. Nicky Barr, the centre's director, observed that the perpetrators had likely cut through a perimeter fence, with scuff marks inside the memorial probably caused by the falling blocks. She expressed immense disappointment, stating, "It is hugely disappointing that a memorial this county has worked so hard for, that honours the dead of Bomber Command, has been subjected to this kind of abject vandalism." She also conveyed the immense pride felt for the spire, which locals affectionately call 'our memorial', highlighting the significant effort invested despite its recent construction just a year ago. Barr reiterated the act as a clear sign of disrespect. Furthermore, she warned that anyone attempting to climb the approximately 30-meter high structure, with its paved base, would be putting themselves "at real risk of injury," potentially leading to severe harm and being left stranded. The spire was officially unveiled in October, with approximately 300 Bomber Command veterans in attendance. During World War Two, 125,000 aircrew served in Bomber Command, undertaking 364,514 operational sorties. Of these, a tragic 55,573 aircrew lost their lives, including 25,611 originating from Lincolnshire. Overall, 70% of aircrew were either killed, taken prisoner, or injured.
label: T4

Stuart Jones should have claimed a late equaliser for Bala but headed just wide when Nathan Burke's free-kick found him unmarked at the back post. The return leg at the Rheinpark Stadion in Vaduz is on Thursday, 6 July. Ballymena United or Norwegian side Odd await the winners in the second qualifying round. Bala manager Colin Caton told BBC Wales Sport: "I don't think we started the game very well - we were very flat and wary of knowing the opposition. "We still had good chances and a blatant penalty when Kieran [Smith] has gone through and has been pulled back. "They had two chances in the first half and that's the difference at this level. It's a bit frustrating really... we have had the better chances. "If we get the first goal out there, it's an away goal and they will be in a sticky situation. "They were panicking towards the end here. "It just frustrates me we have done ever so well but you have to take the chances at this level."
label: T1

text: The captain pounced after Kieran Smith 's shot was spilled by Peter Jehle in the visiting goal . Vaduz had led 2 - 0 at half - time after goals in quick succession from Gonzalo Zarate and Maurice Brunner . Stuart Jones should have claimed a late equaliser , but his header from close range flew agonisingly wide of Peter Jehle's post in the dying moments. The home side, having fought back bravely after the early dominance from Vaduz, were left to rue their missed opportunities. Vaduz's first-half superiority, highlighted by the clinical finishes from Gonzalo Zarate and Maurice Brunner, proved decisive. Despite a much improved second-half display from the hosts, spearheaded by Kieran Smith's persistent attacking play, they couldn't find the crucial second goal. Peter Jehle, despite the earlier error, made several crucial saves later on to preserve Vaduz's slender lead. The result meant that Vaduz secured a vital away win, maintaining their strong start to the season and leaving the home side frustrated, knowing they had pushed their opponents all the way after a difficult start. The tactical changes at half-time had clearly galvanised the home team, but ultimately it wasn't enough to overturn the two-goal deficit provided by Zarate and Brunner.

The decisive return leg will be held at Vaduz's Rheinpark Stadion on Thursday, July 6th. The winners will then face either Ballymena United or Norwegian side Odd in the second qualifying round. Bala manager Colin Caton shared his thoughts with BBC Wales Sport: "I don't think we began the game particularly well; we were quite sluggish and overly cautious about knowing our opponents. Nevertheless, we still created good opportunities, including a clear penalty when Kieran [Smith] was pulled back after breaking through. Vaduz capitalized on their two first-half chances, which highlights the fine margins at this level. It's genuinely frustrating, as we had the better chances. If we can secure the first goal in the away leg, it's an away goal, and that will put them in a sticky situation. They seemed to be panicking towards the end here. It simply frustrates me that we performed so well, but at this level, you absolutely have to take your opportunities."

text: The teenager is charged with supplying drugs in East Calder, where police are investigating the death of 15-year-old Dione Melville. Emergency services were called to a house in the town on Sunday morning, but the teenager was pronounced dead a short time later. Officers are currently treating the death as "unexplained". Another two 15-year-old girls were taken to St John's Hospital in Livingston as a precaution. Diona attended West Calder High School. Acting head teacher Lisa Grubb said: "Dione was a popular girl and this is clearly a very upsetting time for her friends and family. "She was an ambitious young lady who had plans to work in hairdressing and in the beauty industry after leaving school in the summer. "She was very focused on her future and the thoughts of the entire school community are with Dione's family and friends at this incredibly sad time." Dozens of tributes have been left on social media by the teenagers' friends. One said: "Rest in paradise, my beautiful girl. You didn't deserve to get taken away from us. Shine bright, fly high and sleep tight babe. I love and miss you forever and ever my girl."

text: James Percival, 66, said he gave mouth-to-mouth resuscitation to newborn Jonathan Percival in the vicarage in Freckleton, Lancashire, in 2014. But Ruth Percival, 30, said she had not seen him make any attempts to revive the baby. The inquest was halted in October when new medical evidence led the coroner to refer the case to prosecutors. In March, the Crown Prosecution Service said there remained "insufficient evidence" to charge anyone. The hearing at Blackpool Town Hall was told that Miss Percival, who has some special educational needs, visited her GP surgery in August 2014 to arrange to terminate a pregnancy, but had been unable to have one because she was too far gone. She agreed she had put her "head in the sand" about the pregnancy and had not told her parents because she was "scared" of their reaction. Mr Percival, who at the time was the vicar of Holy Trinity CE Church in Freckleton, said after she returned home from work in the afternoon on 25 November she spent time in the downstairs toilet. He said at about 15:30 GMT he saw her come out of the bathroom carrying a towel covered with what he believed to be excrement and went outside with her to put it in a bin "when Jonathan's leg came in sight". He told the court: "I said to Ruth, 'this is a baby, you can't put a baby in the bin'." He said he placed the baby on the towel on the floor outside and attempted to resuscitate him. He said the baby "was very, very cold, absolutely lifeless", adding: "The baby was quite clearly dead." The inquest heard that medical evidence showed the baby was alive at the time he was born. Miss Percival said she thought she saw the baby trying to take a breath, but also said: "I kind of thought I did have a miscarriage because to me the baby was dead when he came out of me." Miss Percival and her father gave evidence that Jonathan had the umbilical cord wrapped round his neck. The hearing is due to continue on Tuesday.
label: T1

text: James Percival , 66 , said he gave mouth - to - mouth resuscitation to newborn Jonathan Percival in the vicarage in Freckleton , Lancashire , in 2014 . But Ruth Percival , 30 , said she had not seen him make any attempts to revive the baby . The inquest was halted in October when new medical evidence led the coroner to refer the case to prosecutors . In March , the Crown Prosecution Service said there remained " insufficient evidence to pursue a prosecution against anyone in connection with Jonathan's death. This decision meant that the coroner, Dr. James Adeley, could now resume the inquest into the circumstances surrounding the infant's passing. The hearing, which had initially begun in October of the previous year, aimed to establish the medical cause of death for Jonathan Percival, who was just 36 hours old when he died at the vicarage in Freckleton. During earlier sessions, disturbing details had emerged, including the starkly contrasting accounts from James Percival and Ruth Percival. James Percival, who claimed to have delivered the baby, maintained that he had attempted to resuscitate the infant, performing mouth-to-mouth and chest compressions. He described the baby as being born "blue" and not breathing, prompting his immediate intervention. However, Ruth Percival, the child's mother, presented a vastly different narrative. She testified that she was in the room throughout the critical period and did not observe James Percival making any efforts to revive Jonathan. Her testimony cast serious doubt on his account of the events leading up to the baby's death. The new medical evidence that prompted the coroner to involve prosecutors was not publicly detailed but was understood to have raised specific questions about the circumstances of Jonathan's death and the care he received. Despite this, the CPS concluded that the evidential threshold for criminal charges could not be met. The family of Jonathan Percival, including Ruth Percival, expressed their ongoing desire for a full understanding of what happened to the newborn. The resumed inquest was expected to hear further expert medical testimony and revisit the conflicting accounts from James Percival and Ruth Percival, with the coroner's ultimate goal being to provide a definitive conclusion on the cause and circumstances of Jonathan's tragic death in Freckleton, Lancashire. The legal proceedings continue to bring to light the complexities and emotional toll of the case for all involved, particularly the parents seeking answers.

text: Mencap and the Challenging Behaviour Foundation have spoken of the risks of moving patients hundreds of miles. The warning comes as the results of a serious case review into the abuse of patients at the private hospital near Bristol are due to be released. The abuse was uncovered during secret filming by the BBC Panorama programme. Eleven people have admitted charges of ill-treatment and neglect related to the abuse. South Gloucestershire Safeguarding Adults Board (SAB) commissioned the review, carried out by an independent expert. Mencap and the Challenging Behaviour said they had received 260 reports from families concerning abuse and neglect in institutional care since the Panorama programme was aired in May last year. Their joint report - Out of Sight - detailed a number of serious incidences reported by families, including physical assault, sexual abuse and the overuse of restraint. Mencap chief executive Mark Goldring said: "We fear that unless the government commits to a strong action plan to close large institutions and develop appropriate local services for people with a learning disability, there is a very real risk that another Winterbourne View will come to light." There are currently hundreds of people with a learning disability in assessment and treatment units like Winterbourne View, the charities said. Many of these are located hundreds of miles from home, where people are at particular risk of neglect and abuse, they added. Vivien Cooper, founder of the Challenging Behaviour Foundation, said they had "deep concerns" over patient "safety and welfare". "Many hundreds of people with a learning disability are being sent away to care institutions hundreds of miles from home, where they remain for years unnecessarily, at risk of neglect and abuse," she said. A Department of Health spokeswoman said: "We are clear that wherever possible people should be supported to live in their own homes within their local community. "In a small number of cases people might need access to good quality assessment and treatment services which might include some short periods of in-patient care. "However this is not a substitute for high quality care within the community. "It is vital all services are commissioned properly, reviewed regularly and not used as a long-term solution." Twenty-four patients were transferred from Castlebeck-run Winterbourne View, near Hambrook, following the BBC investigation. The hospital was closed the following month. The criminal charges related to five patients at the hospital. All the defendants are awaiting sentence.
label: T1

text: Mencap and the Challenging Behaviour Foundation have spoken of the risks of moving patients hundreds of miles . The warning comes as the results of a serious case review into the abuse of patients at the private hospital near Bristol are due to be released . The abuse was uncovered during secret filming by the BBC Panorama programme . Eleven people have admitted charges of ill - treatment and neglect related to the abuse . South Gloucestershire Safeguarding Adults Board ( SAB ) commissioned the review , carried out by an independent investigator. The review meticulously examined the systemic failures allowing horrific abuse at Winterbourne View, the private hospital near Bristol. It delved into circumstances leading to patients being placed far from families and communities, a key concern highlighted by Mencap and the Challenging Behaviour Foundation. Their long-standing campaigns consistently warned against inherent risks of distant placements, which isolate vulnerable individuals, hinder family visits, and create environments where neglect and abuse are less likely to be detected. The serious case review, commissioned by the SAB, sought to identify not only direct perpetrators but also broader institutional and commissioning failures. It scrutinised oversight mechanisms, or lack thereof, from local authorities and NHS trusts responsible for patient placement at Winterbourne View. Findings are expected to be stark, revealing how a system designed to protect vulnerable adults failed them catastrophically. The BBC Panorama exposé, using secret filming to uncover shocking abuse, served as a crucial catalyst, forcing a national reckoning with care quality for people with learning disabilities and challenging behaviour in residential settings. The eleven individuals who admitted charges related to ill-treatment and neglect represent a tragic failure of individual responsibility, but the review's scope goes far beyond individual culpability. It aims to provide recommendations to prevent such atrocities. These are anticipated to include a significant shift away from large institutional placements towards smaller, community-based care closer to homes and families. Strong calls are likely for improved regulation, robust inspection regimes, and enhanced staff training. Furthermore, the review is expected to highlight the critical need for better communication between care providers, commissioning bodies, and families, ensuring concerns are heard and acted upon promptly. Mencap and the Challenging Behaviour Foundation have advocated for comprehensive reform, pushing for person-centred care prioritizing individual rights, dignity, and access to a full life within their community. Their warnings about perils of out-of-area placements, often driven by lack of appropriate local provision or cost-saving, have been tragically vindicated by Winterbourne View. The SAB's commitment to releasing the full findings of this independent review demonstrates a crucial step towards transparency and accountability. Lessons from this harrowing episode must drive genuine, lasting change across health and social care sectors, ensuring safeguarding of vulnerable adults remains paramount. The imperative is to learn from systemic failures and implement robust measures to protect those who rely on specialist care, preventing any recurrence of neglect and abuse. The review's findings will undoubtedly inform national policy and practice, reinforcing the urgent need for a fundamental shift in how care is commissioned and delivered for individuals with complex needs, moving from isolated institutional settings towards inclusive, community-based support.

text: The Met Office issued at yellow "be aware" warning of the conditions at 08:45 for the Highlands and parts of Aberdeenshire and central Scotland. The warning of ice and snow falling to about an inch (4cm) on ground above 656ft (200m) and to 3in (10cm) above 1,312ft (400m) is in place until 23:00. Routes affected include the A82 at Altnafeadh and the A9 at Drumochter. The Met Office said: "Be aware that some difficult driving conditions will be encountered today with the possibility of some local transport disruption. text: Campaign group Liberty says the powers, which are used by intelligence agencies to collect large volumes of data from electronic devices, amount to an "assault on our freedom". The Investigatory Powers Act gained royal assent in November. The government has said it will defend the act. Powers covered by the act allow state agencies to control and alter electronic devices, read texts, online messages and emails and listen in on calls, regardless of a suspicion of criminal activity. The act forces communications companies to retain data of the who, where and when, but not the content of people's phone calls, emails, texts and web browsing history. But Liberty wants to challenge the lawfulness of these powers and is asking the public to fund a judicial review. Liberty director Martha Spurrier said: "Last year, this government exploited fear and distraction to quietly create the most extreme surveillance regime of any democracy in history. "Hundreds of thousands of people have since called for this act's repeal because they see it for what it is - an unprecedented, unjustified assault on our freedom." In November 2016, a petition asking the government to repeal the act attracted more than 118,000 signatures. Investigatory Powers Act The act was first proposed by Prime Minister Theresa May when she was home secretary and was approved by the House of Lords on 19 November. Bulk powers are among the most controversial in the legislation, but security services and the government argue that they play a crucial role in counter-terrorism efforts. Last month, the government faced calls to amend the act after the European Court of Justice found the "general and indiscriminate" retention of communications data was illegal. EU judges said communications data could only be retained if it was used to fight serious crime. The BBC's legal correspondent Clive Coleman said the government has said it will vigorously defend the act, which it says protects both privacy and security, had faced unprecedented parliamentary scrutiny and enjoyed cross parliamentary support.

text: Campaign group Liberty says the powers , which are used by intelligence agencies to collect large volumes of data from electronic devices , amount to an " assault on our freedom " . The Investigatory Powers Act gained royal assent in November . The government has said it will defend the act . Powers covered by the act allow state agencies to control and alter electronic devices , read texts , online messages and emails, monitor phone calls and access location data. This controversial legislation, dubbed the 'Snooper's Charter' by critics, grants extensive surveillance capabilities to agencies like MI5, MI6, and GCHQ. Liberty, with director Martha Spurrier at the forefront, argues the act constitutes an "assault on our freedom" by enabling mass surveillance. Spurrier contends it permits indiscriminate data collection on ordinary citizens, setting a dangerous precedent for civil liberties rather than targeting specific threats. She calls it one of the most extreme surveillance laws in a democracy. Despite significant opposition, including from the House of Lords which sought stronger privacy protections, the Investigatory Powers Act gained royal assent. The government, under then-Prime Minister Theresa May, defended the act as vital for national security in the digital age. May argued it merely updated existing powers, bringing transparency and proper oversight through independent judicial commissioners. However, Liberty and other privacy advocates continue to challenge its proportionality. They highlight concerns over bulk data collection, device hacking, and the requirement for internet service providers to retain browsing history for 12 months, viewing these as unacceptable intrusions. Legal challenges are anticipated, potentially reaching the European Court of Human Rights. The act underscores a fundamental tension between state security and individual freedoms, with critics warning of a chilling effect on free expression.

text: The talks come after Papua New Guinea 's Supreme Court ruled the facility unconstitutional , overturning a deal reached between the governments . Australia sends asylum seekers there under its offshore processing policy . Papua New Guinea has now said it will close the facility , but it is not clear when that could happen . Manus Island was first opened in 2001 , and along with Australia 's other offshore processing centres , has played a central role in Australia 's controversial asylum policy . Papua New Guinea 's high commissioner to Australia, Charles Lepani, has indicated that the closure of the Manus Island detention centre will be a gradual process, emphasizing collaboration with Australia for the humane resettlement of the asylum seekers currently housed there. The Supreme Court ruling has put both nations in a challenging position, requiring careful diplomacy to resolve complex human rights and political issues. Lepani stressed that while Papua New Guinea respects the court's decision, the welfare of the detainees remains paramount. He stated the exact timeline for closure is still being determined, but it will not be immediate. This necessitates ongoing discussions between Australia and Papua New Guinea to develop a comprehensive plan for the future of the hundreds of men who have been in limbo for years. The long-standing agreement between the two countries, which saw Australia sending asylum seekers to Manus as part of its 'Pacific Solution' policy, has been a contentious issue internationally, drawing criticism from human rights organizations. The Supreme Court's ruling, which found that the detention of asylum seekers on Manus Island violated their constitutional right to personal liberty, has now forced both governments to confront the moral and legal implications of the policy. The court's decision was a landmark moment, highlighting the inherent tensions between national security policies and fundamental human rights. The Australian government, under Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, has acknowledged the ruling and stated its commitment to working with Papua New Guinea to manage the transition. However, Australia maintains its policy that none of the asylum seekers sent to Manus will ever be resettled in Australia. This stance further complicates the situation, as viable third-country resettlement options are limited. Charles Lepani has called for international cooperation and support to find sustainable solutions, suggesting the international community has a role to play in addressing this humanitarian crisis. The future of the Manus facility, and Australia's entire offshore processing system, remains uncertain, with significant pressure mounting on both governments to provide clarity and compassionate solutions for those affected. The ruling underscores the importance of judicial independence in upholding human rights, even in the face of complex bilateral agreements. The protracted nature of the issue and the lack of immediate clear solutions mean that the closure will be a carefully managed, multi-stage process, involving extensive diplomatic efforts and logistical planning. Papua New Guinea is committed to upholding its legal obligations while also seeking to maintain strong bilateral ties with Australia. The international community continues to monitor the situation closely, awaiting concrete steps towards the resolution of this prolonged humanitarian challenge. The welfare of the detainees and their eventual resettlement is the primary focus for all parties involved.

text: The fine print of the deal suggests something slightly different, and shows that GM has in fact taken a hit of up to ¬£6bn in order to get shot of Vauxhall and Opel. First, a big chunk of the price - three-quarters of a billion pounds - is not for car plants, but for loans taken out by the owners of Opel and Vauxhall cars through GM's finance arm. Peugeot is paying four-fifths of the book value of the outstanding loans. Second, GM is keeping most of the outstanding pension liabilities. Peugeot will take on a few of the schemes, and is being paid ¬£2.6bn by GM for agreeing to do so. Third, the Detroit giant will take an accounting hit of ¬£3.2bn on the deal - a confirmation that the value it had placed on Opel and Vauxhall in its own books was born more out of hope and the scale of past investments than any solid expectation of future profits. GM's financial agony does not mean, of course, that Vauxhall and Opel will not prosper under their new owner. Peugeot thinks it can squeeze ¬£1.5bn of savings out of the combined operation, and if it can help the French carmaker break into new markets the deal will have done its job. GM, meanwhile, continues to shrink its ambitions and focus on the future. Since it was bailed out by the US government in the aftermath of the financial crisis, it has closed in America the Oldsmobile, Saturn, Hummer and Pontiac brands, and ditched its plants in Australia, where it had made cars since 1931. This might be seen as a retreat from former glories, but it may instead reflect GM's hard-headed conviction that the future is China - where it is the strongest of the US players - and electric and self-driving cars, where America, not Europe, leads the way.

The focus for Vauxhall under its new ownership will be on platform sharing with Peugeot models, standardizing components, and rationalizing the product portfolio to improve profitability. This move signals a definitive shift in GM's global strategy, allowing it to concentrate resources on more lucrative markets like North America and China, and invest heavily in future technologies such as electric and autonomous vehicles. text: Star Randel-Hanson killed Derick Marney, 70, at a flat in Vernon Terrace, Brighton, in May 2015. He broke down and confessed to the murder 10 days later he went to tarot reader Jayne Braiden on Brighton seafront. She alerted police but was told it was a "non-emergency" so she waited an hour with the killer for an officer to come. Ms Braiden told BBC Radio 5 Live: "By the time we got to the devil card he broke down and started crying. "It's the first time I've dealt with murder before. It was a shock but you have to be professional and I needed to keep him calm." Mr Marney died from a six-inch (15cm) stab wound to his side, which punctured his vital organs. Sussex Police said it was "not clear" what motivated Randel-Hanson - who was jailed for life on 9 May - to carry out the murder. After gaining the defendant's trust, Ms Braiden asked him whether she could go outside to call the police. He agreed. She said: "I explained [to the 999 operator] I was a tarot reader and told her a man had confessed to murder. "She told me it was a non-priority call and I needed to ring the non-emergency number. "Unfortunately they didn't believe me, but I'm not surprised at that." She said she then bought Randel-Hanson a drink from a shop next door and waited 55 minutes for police to arrive. "I asked him if it was ok if I took notes... I took names, places, where he had been stabbed and where the body was," she said. "I didn't ask him why, and to be fair I don't think he wanted to talk to me about that. "We joked about the time it took the police to come. "He was getting tense at that point as I was not only looking for police through the glass doors, he was as well." Sussex Police later admitted the call had been given the wrong level of priority. A spokesman said it has been discussed with the call handler concerned and "suitable advice was given".

But the testimony contained little new information and Republicans appeared confident in plans to press forward on key initiatives, such as loosening financial rules. text: Andreea Cristea is the fifth victim of the attack on 22 March, in which Khalid Masood drove into crowds on Westminster Bridge then stabbed a policeman to death, before being shot dead himself. Ms Cristea, 31, who was on holiday with boyfriend Andrei Burnaz, had been in hospital since the attack. It has emerged that Mr Burnaz had been planning to propose during the day out. A family statement confirmed Ms Cristea, who was an architect, had died on Thursday. The family said: "After fighting for her life for over two weeks, our beloved and irreplaceable Andreea - wonderful daughter, sister, partner, dedicated friend and the most unique and life loving person you can imagine - was cruelly and brutally ripped away from our lives in the most heartless and spiritless way. "She will always be remembered as our shining ray of light that will forever keep on shining in our hearts." The family said they were "deeply touched and eternally grateful" to the "never-ending dedication" of the medical staff who treated Ms Cristea, saying their "kindness and empathy are beyond compare". "There are no words to even begin to describe the crushing pain and emptiness that is left in our hearts," they continued. Mr Burnaz, who sustained a broken foot in the attack, visited Westminster Bridge last week to lay a single white rose. The couple were in London to celebrate Mr Burnaz's birthday and he had been planning to propose to Ms Cristea that day, Romania's UK ambassador Dan Mihalache told the BBC. He said it was thought Masood's car had mounted the pavement and hit Mr Burnaz, before pushing Ms Cristea into the Thames. Mayor of London Sadiq Khan said he was "deeply saddened to hear of the death of Andreea Cristea". He tweeted: "Londoners hold her & her loved ones in our thoughts today." The other people killed on the bridge were Aysha Frade, 44, who worked at a London sixth-form college, US tourist Kurt Cochran, 54, from Utah, and retired window cleaner Leslie Rhodes, 75, from south London. Father-of-two PC Keith Palmer was fatally stabbed outside Parliament. Relatives of those killed joined members of the Royal Family at a "service of hope" held at Westminster Abbey on Wednesday. Ms Cristea's family said they would now like money donated for her recovery to be given to charity.
label: T1

text: Tyson Fury should be banned from boxing for comments which made him sound "like Hitler", Wladimir Klitschko says.
label: T3

text: British world heavyweight boxing champion, Tyson Fury, issued an apology last month for a video shared online that featured homophobic, sexist, and anti-Semitic remarks. His upcoming opponent, former champion Klitschko, who is set to face Fury in Manchester on July 9, expressed his dismay, stating: "I was stunned by his comments. When he spoke about Jewish people, he sounded like Hitler. The man is an imbecile." The 40-year-old Ukrainian, who suffered his first defeat in 11 years to Fury last November, added: "We cannot have a champion like him. He either needs to be silenced, defeated in the ring, or suspended, because we mustn't allow more hatred to be spread. I am fighting someone who struggles to control what he says." The Campaign Against Antisemitism has also demanded a ban for Fury and lodged a complaint with the British Boxing Board of Control. Fury, the undefeated 27-year-old who captured the WBA and WBO heavyweight belts from Klitschko in their initial encounter, later expressed regret for causing offense and pledged to improve his behaviour "as an ambassador of British boxing." He also faced backlash following his victory over Klitschko last year, when remarks concerning homosexuality, paedophilia, and women prompted over 100,000 individuals to sign an online petition requesting his removal from the BBC's 2015 Sports Personality of the Year shortlist.
label: T4

text: The visitors closed on 293-9 at the end of day three, with a lead of 260. Jacques Rudolph's wait for a first Championship hundred in 2016 continued as he chopped onto his stumps for 56. Earlier, Essex had been bowled out for 319, with Craig Meschede (5-84) taking his first five-wicket haul in the Championship this season. The home side secured promotion and the second-tier title by passing 250 in their first innings, thanks largely to a century from captain Ryan ten Doeschate, who added eight to his overnight score before falling for 117. With the ball, Ten Doeschate (2-20) removed both Rudolph and Bragg (54) in his first over, the latter having passed 1,000 Championship runs for the season, after the pair had shared a second-wicket stand of 89. Glamorgan lost six wickets for 36 runs but Mark Wallace (75 not out) and Timm van der Gugten (32) helped push their advantage above 250. Glamorgan batsman Will Bragg told BBC Wales Sport: "The four-day game can ebb and flow, but Wally (Mark Wallace) showed some great resilience and put us in a competitive position going into the last day. "I find it's hard to be consistent in a long season so it's pleasing from that point of view (to reach 1,000), I find more consistency batting at three. "I've felt like I haven't given my wicket away much at all this year which is pleasing. "From a team point of view it's been disappointing but there are positive signs with the youngsters coming through and we've a lot to build upon."
label: T1

text: The visitors closed on 293 - 9 at the end of day three , with a lead of 260 . Jacques Rudolph 's wait for a first Championship hundred in 2016 continued as he chopped onto his stumps for 56 . Earlier , Essex had been bowled out for 319 , with Craig Meschede ( 5 - 84 ) taking his first five - wicket haul in first-class cricket for Glamorgan. His accurate seam bowling ripped through the Essex middle order, claiming the crucial scalps of Simon Harmer and Neil Wagner as Essex were dismissed for 319. Earlier, Alastair Cook had made a patient 90, but Meschede's spell truly restricted Essex. Glamorgan began their second innings with a 26-run deficit. Openers Nick Selman (41) and Jacques Rudolph built a steady platform. Rudolph, despite his eventual dismissal, looked largely untroubled for much of his 125-ball stay, striking seven boundaries. His uncharacteristic lapse saw him drag a delivery from Jamie Porter onto his stumps, ending his aspirations of a century. His departure at 110 for 2 brought Marnus Labuschagne (28) to the crease, who was then trapped lbw by Sam Cook. The Glamorgan middle order faced a testing period. Chris Cooke battled for his 35, and Kiran Carlson added 22, but wickets fell regularly as Essex bowlers exploited the variable bounce. A late cameo from Ryan Thomas, who hit a valuable 18 not out, helped extend the lead as the light faded. The visitors will hope their tailenders can add valuable runs on day four to set Essex a challenging target, with the pitch showing signs of wear and tear, promising more assistance for the spinners. Rudolph's earlier efforts, alongside Meschede's disciplined bowling, have put Glamorgan in a strong position, but the final day promises to be tense. The match remains finely poised, with Glamorgan holding the upper hand thanks to their consistent batting and Meschede's destructive spell.
label: T2

text: Division Two champions Essex will need to chase a sizeable target on the final day to beat Glamorgan at Chelmsford.
label: T3

text: At the close of day three, the visiting team had reached 293 for 9, establishing a lead of 260 runs. Jacques Rudolph's pursuit of his inaugural Championship century in 2016 was prolonged when he was dismissed for 56, hitting the ball onto his own stumps. Previously, Essex had been dismissed for 319, with Craig Meschede achieving his first five-wicket haul of the Championship season, ending with figures of 5 for 84. The host team confirmed their promotion and clinched the second-tier title by surpassing 250 runs in their first innings, primarily due to captain Ryan ten Doeschate's century; he contributed an additional eight runs to his overnight total before being out for 117.
